meanings: To renounce or give up a throne, right, power, claim, responsibility, or the like, especially in a formal manner.
examples: The old president of the company decided to abdicate his role.
King Edward VIII abdicated his throne to marry the love of his life.
further_information: Abdicate is typically used when stepping down from a higher position of power in an organization, institution, or a country.
Originated from the Latin word ab + dicates meaning 'away, from' + 'declare.'
Can be confused with abnegate (verb) which means to deny or renounce something.

meanings: Deviation from what is normal, expected, or usual; Departure from truth, morality, etc.
An irregularity from the normal.
examples: Mary's sudden outburst was an aberration from her calm demeanor.
If a person can roll his tongue, he is thought to have a genetic aberration.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word ab + errare meaning 'away from' + 'to stray.'
Aberration can also mean a temporary mental irregularity or disorder.
In Astronomy, an aberration (of light) is the appearance of a heavenly body in a position different from its actual or true location in space due to Earth's movement.

meanings: Causing or deserving strong dislike or hatred. Feeling or showing strong dislike or hatred.
examples: John's abhorrent behavior caused him to get kicked out of the cafe.
He woke up due to the abhorrent noise made by the passing train.
further_information: Originated from ab + horrere meaning 'away from' + 'to shudder.'
The synonym repugnant implies a stronger meaning of disgust and aversion.

meanings: To act in accordance with rules.
To endure without yielding.
examples: The students must abide by the rules of the school or get punished.
I said I would abide by their decision and follow them.
further_information: Commonly used in the phrase abide by meaning 'to put up with or tolerate.'
Originated from the Old English a + bidan or gebidan meaning 'remain, wait, or delay.'
The phrases 'submit to,' 'stand for,' and 'put up with' have the same meaning as abide.
Might be confused with abode (noun) which means 'a place where a person lives.'

meanings: Any material or substance used for grinding, polishing, etc. (n.)
Causing damage, wear, or removal of surface material by grinding or rubbing. (adj.)
Causing irritation, annoy, or ill will. (adj.)
examples: The athlete was banned from playing future games for using abrasive language.
The carpenter is using an abrasive to smoothen the furniture.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word ab + radere meaning 'away from' + 'to scrape.'
Its synonym irritating denotes a stronger connotation: 'causing annoyance or pain.'

meanings: To hold oneself back voluntarily, especially from something regarded as improper or unhealthy.
To choose not to do or have something.
examples: If you want to live healthy, you should abstain from drinking too much soda.
Marcus found it difficult to abstain from sleeping during the movie.
further_information: Abstain also refers to 'to refrain from casting one's vote' as in during an election.
Originated from the French word abstenir meaning 'to withhold oneself.'

meanings: An extremely plentiful or over-sufficient quantity or supply.
An ample quantity.
examples: New York City is a metropolis with an abundance of high rise buildings.
There is an abundance of fruits in the forest.
further_information: Abundant is the adjective form of abundance.
Related to the French word abundance and originated from the Latin word abundantia meaning 'fullness, plenty.'
The word plenty connotes 'sufficient enough to supply need' while abundance means 'more than what is needed or in excess.'

meanings: Extremely poor or bad.
Immeasurably low or deep, as in like an abyss.
examples: Since Marc played video games the whole week, he earned an abysmal score on the test.
The number of audience attending the concert was abysmal and way lower than their expectations.
further_information: The word was first recorded in mid 1600s combining abysm (an abyss) + -al.
A related adjective is abyssal which means 'unfathomable' or 'relating to the bottom of ocean depths.'

meanings: Officially recognized as meeting the essential requirements, as of academic excellence. (adj.)
To give official authorization to or approval of. (v.)
examples: The charity is accredited by the government and officially allowed to raise funds.
Jonathan is working hard to become an accredited teacher.
further_information: Accredited is typically used to refer to a recognized educational institution that maintains a certain standard of qualification.
It can also mean 'recognized as outstanding,' for example, 'He is an accredited scientist.'

meanings: A practice that emphasizes direct vigorous action especially in support of or opposition to one side of a controversial issue.
Consists of efforts to promote, impede, or direct social, political, economic, or environmental reform with the desire to make improvements in society.
examples: Hunger strike is a form of activism that was used by Mahatma Gandhi.
Participating in discussions and debates is an important part of activism.
further_information: The plural word Movements is related to activism which means 'actions or activities by a group of people with the same advocacy.'
Originated from the German word Aktivismus first recorded in 1905.

meanings: To regard with wonder, pleasure, or approval.
To feel respect and approval for (someone or something).
examples: I admire his perseverance in finishing his studies despite working two jobs.
One can just admire the beauty of nature on a nice spring day and momentarily forget all troubles.
further_information: To admire a person is to 'hold someone in high regard.'
Originated from the late 1500s' Latin word admirari meaning 'to wonder at.'
The synonym adore implies a stronger meaning: 'to worship.'

meanings: To urge to a duty.
To reprove or scold, especially in a mild and good-willed manner.
examples: The teacher admonished him for forgetting his homework at home.
I admonished him to eat healthier and exercise more.
further_information: While reprimand is a synonym, it implies severe and formal warning.
Berate also denotes a stronger meaning: 'to scold vehemently.'
Originated from the Middle English words amonesche, admonesse, and amones.

meanings: Expert or nimble in the use of the hands or body.
examples: He is proving to be an adroit doctor who has saved many lives.
You have to be an adroit soccer player to qualify for the team.
further_information: From the mid-17th French phrase à droit meaning 'on the' + 'according to right.'
The related term dexterous is almost an exact synonym, meaning: 'skillful in the use of hands or body.'

meanings: Pleasantly easy to approach and to talk to.
examples: John is a popular boy with an affable smile.
We need an affable salesperson to increase the number of customers.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word ad + fari meaning 'to' + 'speak.'
Affable implies being open to conversations while its synonym polite implies agreeable manner in general.

meanings: To state or assert positively.
examples: Singing the team anthem affirms one's loyalty to their sports team.
The museum curator cannot affirm which of the paintings is genuine.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word ad + firmus which means 'to' + 'strong.'
The synonym assert implies a stronger meaning of confidence or agreement.
In Law, affirm means 'to state something solemnly before a court or magistrate, but without an oath.'

meanings: Having an abundance of wealth, property, or other material goods.
examples: He desires a more affluent lifestyle and is willing to work hard for it.
The high-end restaurant attracts affluent customers especially on weekends.
further_information: From the Latin word ad + fluere meaning 'to' + 'flow.'
An older usage of affluent means 'a stream or river that flows into a larger stream.'
Do not confuse with effluent which means waste liquid.

meanings: Formed by the conjunction or collection of particulars into a whole mass or sum.
To bring together; collect into one sum, mass, or body.
examples: This aggregate rock is made up of various minerals and elements.
This group is an aggregate of students from different districts.
The samples collected in the swamp should be aggregated in the laboratory.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word ad + grex/greg meaning 'toward' + 'a flock.'
Aggregate is commonly used in science to describe small samples or elements being combined, specifically in Geology.

meanings: A physical disorder or illness, especially of a minor or chronic nature.
examples: She is suffering from a rare ailment and several medicines have been ineffective.
The doctor is quite good at curing common ailments.
further_information: It is a two-part word ail + ment. Ail is from an old English word eglan meaning 'to trouble or plague.' -ment is a suffix from the Latin -mentum which is added to words to imply 'as a result of a certain action.'

meanings: To interchange repeatedly and regularly with one another in time or place.
Being in a constant state of succession or rotation; Constituting an alternative.
examples: You have to alternate with your brother in mowing the lawn.
Create an alternate email for your social media accounts so your school email's inbox is not flooded with notifications.
The alternate teacher is liked by the students and the faculty.
further_information: The verb and adjective form evolved in the 1500s from the Latin alternus meaning 'one after the other.'
Related to the word alternative which means 'giving a limited number of options.'

meanings: To gather for oneself.
examples: My father loved comic books and amassed a great number of them in his collection.
Amassing a large number of followers on Twitter is difficult.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word massa which means 'lump.'
The synonym hoard implies collecting a large amount of something valuable that needs to be guarded.

meanings: Ready or willing to answer, act, agree, or yield.
examples: Some leaders like amenable team members in order to avoid conflict in the team.
He was an easy going child and amenable to change.
further_information: Originated from the French phrase à + mener meaning 'to' + 'lead.'
Credulous could be mistaken as a synonym of amenable, but it means naïve or gullible.

meanings: Descending or claimed from ancestors/forefathers.
examples: Our family's ancestral home needs to be regularly maintained and renovated.
Having blue eyes is an ancestral trait which dates back to my great-great-grandfather.
further_information: Ancestral evolved from the Latin word ante + cedere which means 'before' + 'to go.'
Ancestor (n.) should not be confused with descendant which means successor or offspring.

meanings: To supply with critical or explanatory notes.
examples: It is quite challenging to annotate the works of Shakespeare.
You are free to annotate the textbooks with supplemental notes.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word ad + nota meaning 'to' + 'a mark.'
Annotate is slightly different from comment, as the latter implies a casual 'remark or observation.'

meanings: A deviation from the common rule, type, arrangement, or form.
examples: Kevin's calm and quiet demeanor is an anomaly in this noisy class.
An anomaly in the results of the laboratory tests caused the experiment to be halted.
further_information: Originated from the Greek noun anomalos which is rooted in the word compound an + homalos meaning 'not' + 'even.'
Its synonym aberration implies an 'error or deviation' from the norm.

meanings: Having or showing little or no emotion.
Not interested or concerned.
examples: His apathetic behavior did not go over well with his manager, and he was fired.
The boy showed an apathetic attitude towards his homework.
further_information: Originated from the Greek word a + pathos meaning 'without' + 'emotion or feeling.'
Evolved from apathy + pathetic.

meanings: The tip, point, or vertex.
At the point of climax or peak.
examples: His time as the president of the company is the apex of his career.
They reached the apex of the mountain around noon and set up camp.
further_information: Apex remains relatively unchanged from its Latin root word apex meaning 'summit, tip, or top.'
The synonyms climax and culmination typically refer to abstracts and ideas such as 'climax of the movie' and not a location.

meanings: Causing dismay or horror.
examples: He was dismissed because of his appalling actions and inexcusable behavior.
The appalling crime was reported all over the world.
further_information: Originated from the French word a + palir meaning 'to' + 'grow pale.'
Appalling implies a stronger emotion than astounding or awful.

meanings: Capable of being easily perceived or understood.
Seemingly real or true, but not necessarily so.
examples: It was apparent by the look on his face that he was the winner of the national lottery.
The results from his examination are pretty apparent and show that he is in good health.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word apparere which means 'appear or to come in sight.'
It can also mean as 'being entitled to a right of inheritance such as property, throne, etc.,' as in heir apparent.

meanings: Sufficient to be readily perceived or estimated.
examples: There is an appreciable difference in doing just enough and going the extra mile.
She has to work harder because of her appreciable learning issues.
further_information: Originated from the Late Latin word ad + pretium meaning 'to' + 'price' or 'to rise in value.'
Appreciable is used when something is tangible, quantifiable, or obvious.
May be confused with appreciative which means to show gratitude.

meanings: Uneasy or fearful about something that might happen.
examples: The captain was apprehensive for the safety of the firefighters during the fire.
After a lot of practice, she was less apprehensive of her ability to ride a bicycle.
further_information: Originated from Latin word ad + 'prehendre' meaning 'to' + 'seize.'
The word apprehend has similar roots but means to arrest someone, or to understand a concept.

meanings: Subject to individual will or judgment without restriction.
Based on a random choice or personal whim rather than any reason or system.
examples: An arbitrary behavior is not healthy among friends and can create tension.
It was an arbitrary decision to pardon him of his offenses.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word arbiter meaning 'judge, supreme ruler.'
In Mathematics, arbitrary means '(of a constant or other quantity) of unspecified value.'

meanings: Having a distinctive and pleasant smell.
A plant, drug or medicine yielding a fragrant smell.
examples: The garden is quite aromatic during spring and summer.
Her aromatics help her relax when she is doing yoga.
further_information: Originated from the Greek word aromatikos (a form of the word aroma) which means 'giving out an aroma or sweet smell.'
In Chemistry, aromatic means 'of or relating to specific organic compounds.'

meanings: Making claims or pretensions to superior importance or rights.
Characterized by or proceeding from sense of superiority, self-importance, or entitlement.
examples: Drew's arrogant behavior is the result of her being ridiculously rich.
His arrogant claims were found to be false during the investigation.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word ad + rogare meaning 'to' + 'ask or entreat.'
Arrogant is often linked to aggressive and loud behavior.

meanings: Expressed clearly in distinct syllables.
To utter clearly and distinctly.
examples: His articulate speech won many hearts and minds.
The teacher carefully articulated the project instruction.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word articulus (diminutive form of artus, 'a joint') which means 'to be a part of.'
Articulate usually describes a person who can speak well, usually with charisma and charm.

meanings: Mounted projectile-firing guns or missile launchers.
The troops or the branch of an army concerned with the use and service of such weapons.
examples: The army's advanced artillery won them the war.
The attacking artillery is quite intimidating to the enemies.
further_information: Its definite origin is the Old French word artillier meaning 'to provide with engines of war.'
Also attributed to Latin articulium 'joint,' Latin apere 'to attach,' or Old French atillier 'to equip.'

meanings: Moving upwards or rising in power or influence.
examples: The ascendant political party is winning all elections.
The King desperately looked for ways to defeat the ascendant enemy.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word ad + scandere meaning 'to' + 'climb.'
It can also be spelled as ascendent.
In astrology, ascendant means 'the point on the ecliptic at which it intersects the eastern horizon at a particular time, typically that of a person's birth.'

meanings: To fix or determine the amount of (damages, a tax, a fine, value etc.).
To estimate officially the value of (property, income, etc.) as a basis for taxation.
examples: Tom's house is being assessed so he can put it up on the market.
The damage from the fire was assessed at 400,000 dollars.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word ad + sedere meaning 'to' + 'sit.'
Assess is to determine a value while evaluate implies observation and measurement.

meanings: To take in and understand fully.
To absorb and digest.
examples: Children need to be able to assimilate new ideas.
She had to assimilate a lot of information on her first day of class.
further_information: Originated from Latin ad + similis meaning 'to' + 'like.'
Assimilate implies combination of new information and facts into what you already know.

meanings: To overwhelm with amazement.
Shock with wonder or surprise.
examples: The librarian was astounded by the number of books missing from the shelves.
He was astounded by the awesome present from his mother.
further_information: The original Vulgar Latin extonare evolved into the early form of the word in Middle English.
Astound means 'general surprise' while bewilder and confound imply 'surprise and confusion.'

meanings: Having insight or shrewdness.
examples: Dr. Washington is an astute member of the faculty and an award-winning researcher.
The investigator's astute observation solved the case quickly.
further_information: From the Latin word astus meaning 'craft.'
Astute implies 'expertise in a field' while crafty means 'clever at achieving one's aims by indirect or deceitful methods.'

meanings: To make larger; enlarge in size, number, strength, or extent.
examples: His fortune is augmented by the success of his business.
The plan is to augment our current solution to solve the root cause of the problem.
further_information: From the Latin word augere meaning 'to increase.'
In Linguistics, augment means 'a vowel prefixed to past tenses of verbs in Greek and other Indo-European languages.'

meanings: Severity/hardness of manner, life, etc.
Difficult economic conditions caused by reduced government spending.
examples: The spendthrift man did not believe in austerity.
The austerity measures taken by the government makes the lives of the people more difficult.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word austerus meaning 'severe.'
Its root austere means 'harsh and rigid.'

meanings: Showing great enthusiasm for or interest in.
examples: She is an avid comic book collector who regularly attends comic conventions.
The actor ensured that he made time for his avid fans.
further_information: From the Latin word avere meaning 'to crave.'
The word obsess is related to avid, but the former implies 'extreme dedication and interest.'

meanings: An overwhelming feeling of reverence, admiration, fear, etc., produced by that which is grand, sublime, extremely powerful, or the like.
To inspire with reverence or dread.
examples: Jessica is in awe of the places she visited during her European trip.
She's awed by the fact that she is meeting her music idol.
further_information: Originated from the evolution of the Old English ege which means 'terror or dread' and Old Norse agi meaning 'fright.'
Related to but not similar to awestruck which means 'horrified or very surprised.'

meanings: Scientific instrument that measures atmospheric pressure.
Anything that indicates changes.
examples: A new barometer is essential for accurate weather prediction.
The quizzes are a good barometer of improvements in scholastic performance.
further_information: Originated from the combination of the Greek word baros meaning 'weight' and the English word '-meter.'
Barometer can also mean 'something that measures or identifies.'

meanings: Coming or being after the customary, useful, or expected time.
Late, delayed, or detained.
examples: Belated birthday greetings are still very much appreciated and enjoyed.
We started the discussion without the belated participant because our timeline is hectic.
further_information: Originated from the English be + late which means delayed.
In 16th century, belated meant 'overtaken by the night.'

meanings: To emit a hollow, loud, animal cry, as from a bull or cow.
An act or sound of bellowing.
examples: Her bellowing startled the entire auditorium and alarmed everyone.
The cow's bellow is loud enough to be terrifying and made the kids cry.
further_information: Evolved from the Old English word bylagan meaning 'to sound or roar.'
Bellow is louder than a scream or a yell.

meanings: Characterized by or expressing goodwill or kindly feelings.
Intended for benefits rather than profit.
examples: Mary was attracted to the benevolent attitude of the group.
The school received generous gifts from the benevolent alumni.

meanings: A ship’s allocated place at a wharf or dock.
A bed or bunk in a vessel or train, usually narrow and fixed to a wall.
examples: It was a sad goodbye for the sailors when the ship left its berth.
She suffers from seasickness and keeps to her berth.
further_information: Originated from the English word bear + th meaning 'adequate sea room.'
Berth may also mean 'a job or position.'
A popular idiom give a wide berth to means 'to stay away from or steer clear.'

meanings: Able to speak two languages with the expertise of a native speaker.
examples: Miko grew up in a bilingual community which speaks English and Japanese.
Being able to speak fluent English and Japanese, she is considered bilingual.
further_information: From the Latin word bi + lingua meaning 'having two' + 'tongue.'
A person who can speak several languages is called multilingual or polyglot.

meanings: Any of several games played with hard balls of ivory or of a similar material that are driven with a cue on a cloth-covered table enclosed by a raised rim of rubber.
examples: He is getting better at playing billiards, and he’s planning on joining competitions.
Billiards is a type of mental sport which requires strategy and planning.
further_information: Evolved from the French word bille meaning 'stick of wood' and Medieval Latin billia meaning 'tree trunk.'
While usually interchangeable, pool is a smaller table game.

meanings: A long, often cylindrical, cushion or pillow for a bed, sofa, etc.; something that helps support weight.
To add to, support, or uphold.
examples: The wooden skeleton of the new house needs more bolster for safety.
A good compliment bolstered her confidence.
further_information: Evolved from Old Norse bolstr, Danish, Swedish, and Dutch bolster which means 'to swell.'
A more common synonym is support.

meanings: Something to be thankful for; a benefit or blessing for which one should be grateful.
examples: A generous donation to the orphanage is a huge boon for the kids.
The new train will be a boon to many travelers.
further_information: Originated from Old French word bon meaning 'good.'
An older usage of boon means 'a favor or request.'

meanings: A clasp or ornament having a pin at the back for passing through clothing and a catch for securing the point of the pin.
examples: Mina lost the new brooch she bought last week for her birthday.
She values the brooch worn by the women of her family.
further_information: Evolved from the Latin words broochus or broocus meaning 'projecting.'
Brooch should not be confused with broach which means 'to mention or suggest for the first time.'

meanings: A person present but not involved.
examples: A bystander witnessed the car accident yesterday and gave his statement to the police.
Thankfully, no bystander was hurt during the stampede in the concert.
further_information: First recorded in the early 1600s as combination of by + stand + er meaning 'near' + 'stand' + designation of person.
The bystander effect is a social psychological phenomenon in which individuals are less likely to offer help to a victim when other people are present. Related to apathy.

meanings: Harsh discordance of sound.
A discordant and meaningless mixture of sounds.
examples: The cacophony of the city makes one miss the countryside.
The teacher's thoughts were interrupted by the cacophony of students.
further_information: From the Greek work kakos + phone meaning 'bad' + 'sound.'
The direct antonym of cacophony is euphony meaning 'pleasant agreeable sound.'

meanings: Made hard; To be insensitive.
examples: They have a callous attitude towards the plight of the victims.
Wearing leather shoes without the right socks will result in callous on your feet.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word callus or callum meaning 'thick skin.'
Callous is a variant spelling of callus which means 'a thickened and hardened part of the skin or soft tissue, especially in an area that has been subjected to friction.'

meanings: A picture, description, etc., ludicrously exaggerating the peculiarities or defects of persons or things.
examples: She commissioned a caricature of her dog from an amazing artist.
The newspaper's article made a caricature of the current state of the government.
further_information: Originated from the Vulgar Latin word carricare meaning 'to load a wagon or cart.'
Caricatures are often seen in art, while satire is commonly seen in literature.

meanings: Capable of burning, corroding, or destroying living tissue.
Severely critical or sarcastic.
examples: You have to wear gloves during chemistry lab because we'll be using caustic substances.
Her caustic remark shows her abrasive nature and rude attitude.
further_information: Originated from Greek word kaiein meaning 'to burn.'
A caustic attitude is much worse than abrasive behavior.

meanings: A hollow place.
A hollow space or a pit in a tooth, most commonly produced by tooth disease.
examples: The mole burrowed a hollow cavity in the garden and made it home.
I need to visit the dentist to have my cavity filled and make sure my teeth are healthy.
further_information: From the Latin word cavus meaning 'hollow.'
A cavity implies 'an enclosed empty space' while a hole is 'an opening or a gap.'

meanings: To yield or formally surrender to another.
examples: The infantry ceded the previously occupied territory in order to regroup.
In 1867, Russia ceded Alaska to the US.
further_information: Originated from the French word ceder and the Latin word ceded meaning 'to yield.'
The phrase give in implies 'surrender to an ongoing and continuous pressure.'
words.tip: Think 'SEED' - when you plant a seed, you give up control and let nature take over. To cede is to give up or surrender something to someone else.

meanings: To be renowned or well-known.
examples: A celebrated actor was given an Oscar for the first time in years.
This book is a collection of poems by celebrated authors and prominent people.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word celeber/celebr meaning 'frequented or honored.'
The synonym acclaimed implies 'a publicly acknowledged excellence' whereas celebrated implies 'being popular.'
Celebrated is the past tense of celebrate which means to 'party/salute/observe etc.'

meanings: A room or set of rooms, for the storage of food, fuel, etc., wholly or partly underground and usually beneath a building.
examples: The teenagers discovered a secret cellar full of books and paintings.
The restaurant owner wanted a wine cellar built in his restaurant.
further_information: Originated from the Late Latin word cella meaning 'storeroom or chamber.'
The synonym vault implies 'arched enclosed space, typically large.'

meanings: A kind of farmhouse, low and with wide eaves, common in Alpine regions.
examples: The princess wanted an exclusive chalet for her annual ski vacation.
We got lost locating the chalet due to the snowstorm in the mountains.
further_information: Evolved from the Latin casa meaning 'house.'
A chalet is a type of cabin, usually in snowy regions, typically Swiss-style.

meanings: To discipline, especially by corporal punishment.
To criticize severely.
examples: She was chastised for something that was not even her fault.
The teacher chose to give constructive criticism rather than chastise.
further_information: Originated from the Old French chastier meaning 'to punish.'
Should not be confused with chaste which means 'innocent' or 'moral/modest.'

meanings: Continuing for a long time or recurring frequently.
Having long had a disease, habit, weakness, or the like.
examples: The manager gave a final warning to the employee who was a chronic late comer.
Her chronic headache makes life harder for her.
further_information: Originated from the Greek word khronos meaning 'time.'
Chronic is typically used to describe diseases with prolonged or continued symptoms, often severe.

meanings: A loud uproar, as from a crowd of people; a vehement expression of desire or dissatisfaction. (n.)
To utter noisily. (v.)
examples: The clamor from the crowd alerted the police officers that something was wrong. (n.)
They clamored for their ideas during the team meeting and argued a lot. (v.)
further_information: Originated from the Latin word clamare meaning 'to cry out.'
Spelled as clamour in British English.
words.tip: Think 'CLAM' + 'OR' - Imagine a clam opening its shell and screaming loudly! Clamor means a loud noise or outcry from a group of people.

meanings: Characterized by, done in, or executed with secrecy or concealment, especially for purposes of subversion or deception.
examples: The superheroes were on a clandestine mission to save the world.
Their clandestine meeting went unnoticed for quite some time.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word clam meaning 'secretly.'
Clandestine is often used to describe actions and events while hidden is generally used for objects and people.

meanings: A space or opening made by two parts of a body.
A hollow area or indentation.
examples: A chin with a cleft is believed to be quite rare, just like blue eyes.
They discovered a large cleft between the two mountains.
further_information: Originated from the Old High German and Danish kluft meaning 'a split.'
A cleft palate is a medical condition where the mouth is not well-formed during birth.

meanings: To grow together or into one body.
To unite so as to form one mass, community, etc.
examples: During New Year’s Eve, the community coalesces in the town square to celebrate together.
Good ideas usually coalesce into a strong theory used in research.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word cum + alere meaning 'with' + 'nourish.'
Coalesce implies 'natural and gradual formation into a bigger body' while consolidate implies 'to bring together into a unified whole.'

meanings: To treat tenderly; Nurse or tend indulgently.
To cook (eggs, fruit, etc.) in water that is just below the boiling point.
examples: Mothers typically coddle their children when they're sick or under the weather.
A perfect poached egg is usually coddled in water with a bit of vinegar.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word calidus meaning 'warm.'
Not to be confused with the word cuddle which means 'to hold close in an affectionate manner.'

meanings: To live together as if married, usually without legal or religious sanction.
To dwell with another or share the same place, as different species of animals.
examples: Cohabiting usually brings up new challenges for people.
Zoologists often observe different animals cohabiting harmoniously.
further_information: Originated from the Latin co + habitare meaning 'together' + 'dwell.'
Coexist is a more common synonym of cohabit.

meanings: Quality of being logical and consistent.
examples: Legal contracts should have very high coherence and clarity.
Editing your written work is important for coherence.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word com + haerare which means 'together' + 'to adhere, stick.'
Coherence implies clarity of textual or written work.

meanings: To wind into continuous, regularly spaced rings, one above the other.
A connected series of spirals or rings into which a rope or the like is wound.
examples: To create a weak electromagnet, coil a copper wire around a stick.
There was a coil missing inside the machine; that’s why it’s not working.
further_information: Originated from Latin word com + legere meaning 'together' + 'to gather.'
The verb usage of coil implies 'slow, twisting movement.'

meanings: To act together through a secret understanding, especially with evil or harmful intent.
To conspire in a fraud.
examples: There's a rumour that the captain colluded with the other team to lose the game.
The criminals colluded together to hide from the police.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word col + ludere meaning 'together' + 'to play.'
Collude is commonly misspelled as colude which is not a word.
words.tip: Break it down: CO (together) + LUDE (sounds like 'lewd' or sneaky). When people collude, they work together in a sneaky, secret way to do something wrong.

meanings: An interchange of goods or commodities, especially on a large scale between different countries (foreign commerce) or between different parts of the same country (domestic commerce).
examples: E-commerce involves selling and buying of goods and services online.
Most of the country’s commerce revolves around oil exports.
further_information: Originated from Latin word com + merx/merc meaning 'together' + 'merchandise.'
Commerce implies 'a group of business, customers, and other entities acting together to form economic exchange' while business implies 'an occupation, profession, or trade.'
words.tip: Think of 'E-COMMERCE' - buying and selling online. Commerce is all about trading goods and services, like a 'commercial' on TV trying to sell you something!

meanings: Pleased, especially with oneself or one's merits, advantages, situation, etc., often without awareness of some potential danger or defect.
examples: The government officials are too complacent to change old policies.
The sailors' complacent attitude sank the ship and caused the demise of the passengers.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word complacere meaning 'be very pleasing.'
Complacent has a negative connotation as in being smug while confident or contented evoke positive emotions.

meanings: Something that completes or makes perfect.
To complete; form a complement to.
examples: A good salary is a complement to a happy career, but fulfilment is important.
The black dress complements her smooth skin and striking blue eyes.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word complere meaning 'fill up.'
Not to be confused with compliment which means an expression of praise, commendation, or admiration.

meanings: Obeying, obliging, or yielding, especially in a submissive way.
Manufactured or produced in accordance with a specified body of rules.
examples: His compliant nature makes him vulnerable at times.
The product is compliant with the latest standards.
further_information: Evolved in the 1600s from the word com + plere meaning 'with, together' + 'to fill.'
Not to be confused with complaint which means 'to express dissatisfaction.'

meanings: To be calm, tranquil or serene.
examples: A composed leader during a project helps the team focus and solve problems.
Johnny's composed attitude is common among Marines and military personnel.
further_information: Originated from the Old French word com + poser meaning 'with, together' + 'to place.'
Related to compose which is a verb and means 'create/comprise/calm down.'

meanings: A settlement of differences by mutual concessions; an agreement reached by adjustment of conflicting or opposing claims, principles, etc., by reciprocal modification of demands.
To expose or make vulnerable to danger, suspicion, scandal, etc.
examples: A compromise was reached by the two parties to resolve the conflict.
James needs to compromise with the budget committee in order for the project to proceed.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word com + promittere meaning 'with, together' + 'to release, let go.'
A compromise is often misspelled as comprimise which is not a word.

meanings: Having an excessively favorable opinion of one's abilities, appearance, etc.
examples: He's a little conceited; that's why he does not have many friends.
Jonah's conceited attitude is a hurdle to his improvements.
further_information: Originated from the late 14th century word conceiven meaning 'something formed in the mind, thought, notion.'
Conceited implies 'being too proud of one self or an excess of self-confidence.'
words.tip: Think 'I can SEAT myself on a throne because I'm so great!' - Someone conceited has an inflated opinion of themselves and thinks they're better than everyone else.

meanings: Expressing or covering much in few words; brief in form but comprehensive in scope.
examples: Can you make this contract a bit more concise and clear?
The most effective speech is usually concise and direct.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word con + caedere meaning 'completely' + 'to cut.'
Concise, succinct, and terse usually refers to 'speech or writing using few words.'

meanings: To prepare or make by combining ingredients, especially in cookery.
To devise or to make up.
examples: She was able to concoct a delicious dinner in a very short time.
You have to concoct a plan to solve our current problem and deal with future issues.
further_information: Originated from the Latin com + coquere meaning 'together' + 'to cook.'
Its noun form concoction means 'a mixture of various ingredients or elements.'
words.tip: Think 'COOK' - concoct sounds like 'cook it'! When you concoct something, you're mixing ingredients together to create something (like cooking), or making up a creative plan or story.

meanings: To agree.
To coincide.
examples: Does the team concur with the leader’s statement and plan of action?
Their wedding concurred with the holidays and celebrated both.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word con + currere meaning 'together with' + 'to run.'
The synonym approve implies a stronger agreement than concur.
words.tip: Think 'I CONCUR!' - sounds like 'I con-CUR (agree)!' Picture someone nodding and saying 'I concur' in agreement. Also think of events that 'occur' at the same time - they concur!

meanings: Expression of sympathy with a person who is suffering from sorrow, misfortune, or grief.
examples: It is okay to offer condolences to someone who is grieving.
A sincere expression of condolences helps someone deal with difficult situations.
further_information: Originated from the Late Latin word com + dolere meaning 'with, together' + 'to grieve.'
The word condolement is a lesser known synonym of condolence.

meanings: Sweets and chocolates considered collectively.
examples: He likes all kinds of confectionery including candies, cakes, and milkshakes.
The confectionery along Main Street sells the most amazing chocolate cakes.
further_information: Evolved from the Classical Latin word com + facere meaning 'with' + 'to make, to do.'
A bakery usually sells bread and other pastries while a confectionery focuses on sweets.
words.tip: Think 'CONFECTION' - a sweet treat! Break it down: CON (with) + FECTION (making). A confectionery is where sweet treats are made and sold - candies, chocolates, and cakes!

meanings: To face in hostility or defiance.
To present for acknowledgment, contradiction, etc.
examples: To confront your issues is a brave act and essential to being an adult.
The team confronted the urgent problems first.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word con + frons meaning 'with' + 'face.'
To confront someone implies 'facing something/someone to accuse or criticize.'

meanings: Overcrowding, especially in a small area.
An excessive or abnormal accumulation of blood or other fluid in a body part or blood vessel.
examples: No one likes being stuck in a severe traffic congestion.
The doctors will begin treating her pulmonary congestion.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word con + gerere meaning 'together' + 'bring.'
Congestion is sometimes misspelled as conjesion which is not a word.

meanings: Controlled by or done according to one's inner sense of what is right.
Careful and painstaking.
examples: The people want a conscientious government.
Her designs are very conscientious and evoke deep emotions.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word com + scire meaning 'with/thoroughly' + 'to know.'
Conscientious implies 'more attention to detail' compared to careful.

meanings: To permit, approve, or agree; comply or yield. (v.)
Agreement in sentiment, opinion, a course of action, etc. (n.)
examples: She consented to their request and allowed them to visit her villa. (v.)
Can you email me Sarah's consent so we can process the papers? (n.)
further_information: Originated from the Latin with con + sentire meaning 'together' + 'feel.'
Consent implies 'giving permission or approval' while agree is to 'go along with.'

meanings: To bring together (separate parts) into a single or unified whole.
To unite or combine.
examples: The executives decided to consolidate their companies into one large enterprise.
The librarian consolidated the book collection.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word solidus meaning 'solid.'
Consolidated is the adjective form of the word as in 'consolidated document.'

meanings: An evil, unlawful, treacherous, or surreptitious plan formulated in secret by two or more persons.
A combination of persons for a secret, unlawful, or evil purpose.
examples: Many conspiracy theories are simply not true.
The government always tries to protect itself from conspiracies.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word conspirare meaning 'agree, plot.'
Conspiracy is a formal term used in politics, civil law, and criminal law.

meanings: Of the present time. (adj.)
A person belonging to the same time or period with another or others. (n.)
examples: There is an exhibit of contemporary art in the plaza. (adj.)
His contemporaries are very critical of his work. (n.)
further_information: Originated from the Medieval Latin word con + tempus meaning 'together with' + 'time.'
Modern art is those created between the 1860s to 1960s. Any art after that is considered contemporary.

meanings: Deserving of or held in contempt.
examples: Contemptible actions are punishable by law and can get you in jail.
It was contemptible of the employee to embarrass his boss in front of everyone.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word com + temnere meaning 'together' + 'to slight or scorn.'
Contemptible is often misspelled as contemptable which is not a word.

meanings: Tending to argument or strife.
Causing, involving, or characterized by argument or controversy.
examples: Sarah's contentious attitude is a hindrance to the team’s improvement.
We should always handle contentious situations with poise.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word com + tendere meaning 'with, together' + 'to stretch.'
Contentious implies stronger negative feelings compared to debatable.

meanings: Opposite in nature or character. (adj.)
Something that is the opposite. (n.)
examples: Contrary to popular belief, being a celebrity is difficult and requires a lot of work. (adj.)
She presented a very convincing contrary of the argument. (n.)
further_information: Originated from the Latin word contra meaning 'against.'
The synonym hostile evokes a stronger negative emotion.

meanings: Obviously planned or forced.
examples: Everybody knew that was a contrived story which was fake.
The movie plot seems contrived and boring.
further_information: Originated from the Medieval Latin word contropare meaning 'compare.'
Contrived implies artificial.

meanings: To come together or assemble, usually for some public purpose.
examples: The participants are convening in the auditorium.
In case of an emergency, all students and faculty should calmly convene in the open field.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word con + venire meaning 'together' + 'to come.'
Convene implies 'a gathering with a purpose as a group' while summon is 'to call people to attend.'

meanings: A community of persons devoted to religious life under a superior.
The building or buildings occupied by such a society.
examples: The convent is more than 300 years old and needs an immediate renovation.
The city ordered a renovation of the historic convent.
further_information: Evolved from the Middle French word com + venir meaning 'together' + 'to come.'
Modern use of convent implies a community or building for nuns, while monastery is for monks.

meanings: Familiar with, by use or study.
examples: Living in an English-speaking community will make you conversant with the English language faster.
He is very conversant with medieval history.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word com + vertere meaning 'with, together' + 'to turn.'
Conversant implies a certain expertise in a field or topic.
Usually followed by 'with.'

meanings: To carry, bring, or take from one place to another.
To communicate.
examples: In olden times, horses were used to convey water from rivers to villages.
Make sure that you convey your message clearly and directly.
further_information: Originated from the Medieval Latin word con + via meaning 'together' + 'way.'
Convey commonly refers to speech while express refers to emotions.

meanings: To be friendly.
Of or befitting a feast.
examples: Jamie is a convivial wedding host who appeals to his audience.
I was so happy that my new classmates are convivial and friendly.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word con + vivere meaning 'with' + 'live.'
Convivial implies cheerfulness in general which friendly implies easiness to connect with others.

meanings: To struggle or deal with, especially on fairly even terms or with some degree of success.
To face and deal with responsibilities, problems, or difficulties, especially successfully or in a calm or adequate manner.
examples: Manny believes he can cope with any hurdles and problems along the way.
After having a serious illness, he could not cope with living alone anymore.
further_information: Originated from the Greek work kolaphos meaning 'blow with the fist.'
Cope is sometimes confused with coup which is short for the phrase Coup d'état which means 'the illegal and overt seizure of a state by the military or other elites within the state apparatus.'

meanings: Large in quantity or number.
Having or yielding an abundant supply.
examples: She ordered a copious amount of food and drinks for the party.
The farmers are hoping for a copious harvest this year.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word copia meaning 'plenty.' Another word with the same root is cornucopia which is a noun meaning 'abundant supply.'
An older usage of copious means 'profuse in speech or ideas.'

meanings: Courteous and gracious.
Warm and friendly.
examples: Countries maintain a cordial relationship to keep international peace.
Her cordial personality brings many guests to the restaurant.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word cor meaning 'heart..'
While it implies friendliness, cordial can also be used in negative way, as in 'cordial dislike.'

meanings: To make more certain.
To confirm.
examples: The witness corroborated the accident that happened on 10th Street.
My manager can corroborate the fact that I accomplished all my tasks today.
further_information: Evolved from the Latin word robur meaning 'strength.'
Corroborate is typically used in legal situations to confirm the authenticity of certain information.

meanings: A table or display case on which goods can be shown, business transacted, etc. (adj.)
An opposite. (n.)
examples: Proceed to the counter on the left if you want to process your application. (n.)
His counter proposal is not enough to convince the committee. (adj.)

meanings: A messenger, usually traveling in haste, bearing urgent news, important reports or packages, diplomatic messages, etc.
Any means of carrying news, messages, etc., regularly.
examples: The courier is very efficient in delivering packages and mails.
We don't have a courier nearby; you may need to drive downtown.
further_information: Evolved from the Italian word corriere meaning 'to run.'
Should not be confused with the word carrier which means 'a person or thing that carries.'

meanings: An art, trade, or occupation requiring special skill.
To make or manufacture (an object, objects, product, etc.) with skill and careful attention to detail.
examples: Honing your craft takes years of training and practice.
Crafting a beautiful design digitally is very challenging.
further_information: Originated from Old English word craft meaning 'power, physical strength.'
Craft implies 'skills in manual talent or trade' while hobby is 'an activity done to pass the time.'

meanings: Cowardly.
A coward.
examples: He sometimes has the tendency to be craven when faced with big problems.
Everybody thought Jimmy is a craven until he saved a little girl from the burning building.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word crepare meaning 'to crack or creak.'
Craven is not related to the word crave which means 'to want desperately.'

meanings: A ridge or groove produced by folding, heat, pressure, etc.
To make a crease or creases in or on.
examples: Create a crease by folding the paper diagonally.
Don't crease the gift wrapper yet before you use it.
further_information: Altered from the 1600s' word creaste meaning 'a ridge.'
Not related to the word crest which means 'the highest part of anything.'

meanings: A representation of a nativity scene.
A place where small children can be left to be looked after while their parents are doing something else.
examples: A creche is being set up a month before December in front of the church.
Johnny likes staying at the creche when I'm at work.
further_information: Originated from the Old French creche meaning 'a crib, manger, or stall.'
Crib is another synonym for creche.

meanings: Willing to believe or trust too readily, especially without proper or adequate evidence.
examples: People should avoid being credulous during elections and do their research carefully.
My credulous son believes that I am Batman and he is Robin.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word credere meaning 'to believe.'
Being credulous implies 'ignoring available facts or evidence.'

meanings: A crack forming an opening.
examples: Do not go playing too far or you'll fall into a crevice.
The cleaning staff makes sure that all crevices of the hotel are clean.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word crepare meaning 'to rattle, crack.'
Crevice is a variant spelling of crevasse which has a similar meaning.

meanings: In a raw or unprepared state.
Crude oil.
examples: Submit your essay even in its crude draft so I can help you edit.
A delivery of crude will arrive later for the factory machines.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word crudus meaning 'rough, uncooked.'
The word uncouth can also be used as a synonym when referring to behavior or manner, as in 'uncouth person.'

meanings: To reach the highest point, summit, or highest development.
examples: Jenna's efforts and hard work culminated in her graduation.
An amazing musical performance culminated the talent night.
further_information: Originated from Late Latin word columna meaning 'top or summit.'
The synonym climax implies 'a more intense point' than culminate.

meanings: To waste time.
To play mockingly or playfully.
examples: Avoid dallying especially in the morning because we are always late.
The children were told not to dally with the horses without any adults around.
further_information: Originated from the Anglo-French word dalier meaning 'to amuse oneself.'
A related verb is dilly-dally which means 'waste time through aimless wandering or indecision.'

meanings: An inadequate supply.
examples: There is a dearth of well-trained teachers in the region.
During hot, dry summer, there is a dearth of fresh produce.
further_information: Originated from the Old English word deore + th meaning 'precious, costly' + a suffix to indicate nouns of action, state, or quality.

meanings: To reduce in quality or value.
To lower in rank, dignity, or significance.
examples: The value of the painting was debased because of the copycats.
He refuses to debase himself by doing tasks that are beneath his rank.
further_information: Originated from the 1500s' word de + base meaning 'down' + 'low.'
The synonyms demean and shame imply stronger negative emotions than debase.

meanings: Having the power or quality of deciding.
Characterized by or displaying no or little hesitation.
examples: Johnny offered a decisive solution to the team’s urgent issues.
The military needs men with decisive manner and strong conviction.
further_information: Evolved from the Latin word de + caedere meaning 'off' + 'to cut.'
Decisive should not be confused with divisive which means 'tending to cause division or hostility between people.'

meanings: Dignified propriety of behavior, speech, dress, etc.
The quality or state of being decorous, or exhibiting such dignified propriety.
examples: The aristocrats are known for their decorum and elegant demeanor.
The teacher was impressed with the decorum of the students during lunch.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word decor meaning 'beauty, elegance or charm.'
The word demeanor refers to behavior and appearance in general.

meanings: To bend or turn aside; Turn from a straight course or straight line.
examples: She's very good at deflecting mean criticisms and ignoring rude comments.
Neo was amazing when he deflected bullets in The Matrix.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word de + flectere meaning 'away from' + 'to bend.'
Deflect is related to reflect which means 'throw back or mirror.'

meanings: Carefully weighed or considered.
To consider carefully.
examples: The deliberate lie is so obvious to anyone who hears it.
The students deliberated yesterday about the party theme.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word libra meaning 'scales.'
To deliberate emphasizes 'the use of logic and reason.'

meanings: Failing in or neglectful of a duty or obligation.
A person who is delinquent.
examples: The teenagers are showing delinquent behavior.
Study hard so you don't become a delinquent and end up being a failure.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word de + linquere meaning 'away' + 'to leave.'
A related phrase is juvenile delinquent meaning 'a minor who cannot be controlled by parental authority and commits antisocial or criminal acts, as vandalism or violence.'

meanings: Wild with excitement, enthusiasm, etc.
examples: She is feeling delirious because of the high fever and headache.
Maddy is delirious with happiness on winning the lottery.
further_information: Originated from the 1700s' word delirium + ous meaning 'having, full of, having to do with, doing, inclined to.'
Delirious implies 'uncontrollable and intense emotion.'

meanings: To lower in dignity, honor, or standing.
examples: He thinks cleaning is a demeaning job meant only for uneducated people.
He demeaned himself by indulging in vandalism.
further_information: Originated from the 1600s' word de + mean meaning 'down' + 'low quality.'
Demean implies embarrassment or humiliation while punishment refers to 'consequences of violation.'

meanings: A conduct, behavior or attitude.
examples: Jimmy has a friendly demeanor that everybody likes and gains him many friends.
Her demeanor was quite offensive to the group which caused them to boot her out.
further_information: Originated from the Old French word de + mener meaning 'completely' + 'to lead or direct.'
Demeanor refers to behavior or appearance in general, compared to decorum which means 'dignified manner.'

meanings: Termination of existence or operation; Death.
examples: Everybody was so surprised by her tragic demise during her vacation.
The Romans brought about the demise of the Greeks.
further_information: Originated from the Middle French word des + mettre meaning 'away' + 'put.'
In Law, demise means transfer of an estate.

meanings: To reduce to a lower grade, rank, class, or position.
examples: One more violation and you’ll be demoted to the lowest position.
It is rare to demote an officer to a private, but it can happen.
further_information: Originated in the 1880s by combining de + promote meaning 'down' + 'to advance in rank, dignity, position, etc.'
Demote should not be confused with denote which means 'to signify.'

meanings: To be a mark or sign of.
To be a name or designation for.
examples: A high fever often denotes viral or bacterial infection which could be serious.
This trademark denotes high quality.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word nota meaning 'a mark.'
Denote should not be confused with demote which means 'to reduce to a lower grade.'

meanings: To represent by or as if by painting.
To represent or characterize in words.
examples: The character in the novel is depicted as strong and independent.
The painting depicts a peaceful scenery over a cliff.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word de + pingere meaning 'completely' + 'to paint.'
Depict may also mean 'to represent something in different form.'

meanings: To decrease significantly or exhaust the abundance or supply of.
examples: The dry season will deplete the water supply soon.
Be careful with your budget this month or it will be depleted.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word plenus meaning 'full.'
Deplete is commonly misspelled as depleat which is not a word.

meanings: Causing or being a subject of grief or regret.
Causing or being a subject of censure, reproach, or disapproval.
examples: The news about her friend's deplorable accident was surprising.
The auditorium was in a deplorable state after the concert.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word de + plorare meaning 'entirely' + 'weep or cry out.'
The synonyms unfortunate and shameful imply less emotion than deplorable.

meanings: Not original.
Based on another source.
examples: The artist's work is original and not in the slightest bit derivative.
A derivative is not acceptable, as we need an original solution.
further_information: Originated from the Late Latin phrase de + rivus meaning 'from' + 'stream.'
In Mathematics, the derivative of a function represents an infinitesimal change in the function with respect to one of its variables.

meanings: To receive or obtain from a source or origin.
To reach or obtain by reasoning.
examples: The wine is derived from a nearby winery which ensures high quality.
The solution is derived from a complicated computation.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word de + rivus meaning 'from' + 'stream.'
Derive implies 'based on an original source' and is not similar to copy.

meanings: To stop doing something.
examples: The court ordered the website to desist from posting fake news.
The doctors strongly encourage people to desist from smoking.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word de + sistere meaning 'off' + 'stop or come to a stand.'
Desist is typically used in law to stop an activity.
Usually followed by 'from.'

meanings: Deserving to be despised, or regarded with distaste, disgust, or disdain.
examples: He was a despicable man who treated his friends badly.
Despicable actions have no place in this company.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word de + spicere meaning 'down' + 'to look at.'
Despicable implies a stronger emotion compared to bad or hateful.

meanings: Without means of subsistence.
Deprived of, devoid of, or lacking.
examples: He overcame his destitute upbringing to be successful.
The charity helps out destitute people in need.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word de + statuere meaning 'away from' + 'to place.'
In scholastic works, the word penury is used instead of destitution.

meanings: Serving or tending to deter.
Military strength or an ability to defend a country or retaliate strongly enough to prevent an enemy from attacking.
examples: Is a security system an effective deterrent against home invasion?
The government set up a deterrent against terrorists.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word de + terrere meaning 'away' + 'frighten.'
Deterrent implies 'something that keeps something away' compared to obstacle which means 'something that hinders progress.'

meanings: Causing loss or injury.
A detrimental person or thing.
examples: The detrimental decision made her lose the case.
Miscommunication is detrimental to their relationship.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word de + terrere meaning 'away' + 'to rub or wear.'
Detrimental is commonly misspelled as detramental which is not a word.

meanings: To turn aside, as from a route, way, course, etc.
Characterized by deviation or departure from an accepted norm or standard, as of behavior.
A person or thing that departs from the accepted norm or standard.
examples: If we deviate from the suggestions in the map, we will get lost.
A deviated septum is a serious medical condition affecting millions.
They thought he's a deviate just because he lives in the woods far from people.
further_information: Originated from the Late Latin word de + via meaning 'away from' + 'way.'
Should not be confused with devious meaning 'dishonest.'

meanings: (Of route or journey) Departing from the most direct way.
Showing a skillful use of underhand tactics to achieve goals.
examples: Jamie figured that he needs to be devious to win the competition.
There is a devious plot to overthrow the government and create unrest.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word de + via meaning 'away from' + 'way.'
Should not be confused with dubious which means 'hesitating or doubting.'

meanings: Not possessing, untouched by, void, or destitute.
Entirely lacking or free from.
examples: The desert is currently devoid of plant life.
He kept his voice devoid of emotion.
further_information: Originated from the Old French word des + voider meaning 'out or way' + 'to empty.'
It is commonly used in the phrasal verb devoid of.

meanings: Devoted to divine worship or service.
Earnest or sincere.
examples: My family is devout Catholic and we go to Church every Sunday.
He expressed his devout allegiance to the political party.
further_information: Originated from the Old French word de + vovere meaning 'down, away' + 'to vow.'
Should not be confused with devote which means 'give all or a large part of one's time or resources to.'

meanings: A variety of a language that is distinguished from other varieties of the same language by features of phonology, grammar, vocabulary and usage.
examples: It is quite challenging to understand his dialect.
Some dialects sound similar and have the same grammar rules.
further_information: Originated from the Latin dia + legein meaning 'across or between' + 'speak.'
Dialect is 'a regional variety of a language' while a language is 'a distinct body of words and system of communication.'

meanings: Division into two parts, kinds, etc.
Division into two mutually exclusive, opposed, or contradictory groups.
examples: You have to remember that there is a dichotomy between intent and action.
The homework should discuss the dichotomy of social theory and practice.
further_information: Originated from the Greek word dicha + temnein meaning 'in two, apart' + 'to cut.'
In Botany, dichotomy is 'a mode of branching as in plants or stems.'

meanings: To make wider or larger.
To spread out.
examples: When Jimmy is shocked, his eyes become big and dilated.
The pipes need to be replaced because they are dilating.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word di + latus meaning 'apart' + 'wide.'
Dilate implies 'widening or stretching something that is narrow.'

meanings: Constant in effort to accomplish something.
Done or pursued with persevering attention.
examples: Diligent students typically succeed in life and enjoy amazing careers.
The painting shows the artist's diligent efforts and creativity.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word dis + legere meaning 'apart' + 'choose or gather.'
Diligent implies 'hard and careful work done with or employing great care and thoroughness.'

meanings: To be small or tiny.
A small thing or a short person.
examples: With all the tall structures, the nearby house looks diminutive.
The name Will is a diminutive of William.
further_information: Evolved from the Latin word de + minuere meaning 'completely' + 'make small.'
In Grammar, diminutive pertains to a form denoting smallness like the suffix -let.

meanings: Of a dark, dull, or dirty color or aspect.
examples: This apartment is quite dingy; let's look for another one.
You need to wash that cap because it looks dingy.
further_information: Originated from the Old English word dyng meaning 'dung.'
Should not be confused with dinghy which is 'a type of small boat.'

meanings: Of, relating to, or engaged in diplomacy.
Skilled in dealing with sensitive matters or people.
examples: He's elected as a leader because he's diplomatic.
The diplomatic relationship between countries is very important.
further_information: Originated from the Greek word diploos + -oma meaning 'double' + a suffix forming neuter nouns.
A person who deals with the relationship between two or more groups is called a diplomat.

meanings: Lacking the normal or usual necessities and comforts of life, such as proper housing, educational opportunities, job security, adequate medical care, etc.
Disadvantaged persons collectively.
examples: His disadvantaged lifestyle is not an obstacle to his goals.
The soup kitchen is not open to accept the disadvantaged.
further_information: Originated from the Old French word des + avantage meaning 'lack of' + 'position of being in advance of another.'
Disadvantaged is a more polite synonym of the words poor or destitute.

meanings: To cast aside or dispose of.
A person or thing that is cast out or rejected.
examples: You need to discard fruits that are not up to standards.
The traitor was banished from the kingdom to live with other discards in the forest.
further_information: Originated from the English word dis + card meaning 'away' + 'playing card.'
Should not be confused with discord which means 'disagreement between people.'

meanings: To look upon or treat with contempt.
A feeling of contempt for anything regarded as unworthy.
examples: She disdains mass produced products and opts for organic ones.
He expressed disdain towards his brother because of their argument.
further_information: Originated from the Old French word des + deignier meaning 'do the opposite' + 'treat as worthy.'
Disdain is an expression of both indifference and hate.

meanings: To go ashore from a ship.
To remove or unload (cargo or passengers) from a ship, aircraft, or other vehicle.
examples: We disembarked on a beautiful beach with coconut trees lining the whole area.
The captain announced that the passengers should disembark due to an emergency.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word des + barca meaning 'to do the opposite' + 'ship's boat.'
Disembark is typically used when getting off a boat or a ship.

meanings: The lack of enthusiasm.
examples: He felt a strong disinclination to further his studies and chose to start working full time right away.
She showed a disinclination to face up to her issues.
further_information: Negative form of the 1300s' word in + clinare meaning 'into' + 'to bend.'
Disinclination is similar to disinterest.

meanings: Lacking in frankness, candor, or sincerity.
examples: Tom's excuse is rather disingenuous and unsupported by facts.
The student's disingenuous reason for missing the deadline was not believed by the teacher.
further_information: Originated from the 1600s' word dis + ingenuus meaning 'opposite' + 'noble in nature, high-minded.'
An informal synonym of disingenuous is fake.

meanings: To refuse to acknowledge as belonging or pertaining to oneself.
examples: The family disowned him because of his crimes.
He disowned his previous statement and told the truth.
further_information: Originated from the Old English word dis + agen meaning 'lack of' + 'one's own.'
Reject is an informal synonym of disown.

meanings: To speak of or treat badly.
To bring reproach or discredit upon.
examples: It's mean to disparage one's achievements and belittle their efforts.
Do not disparage anyone's efforts as it can burn bridges.
further_information: Negative form of the Latin word par meaning 'equal.'
Disparage is a special type of insult that shows the insulter as superior.

meanings: To cut apart (an animal body, plant, etc.) in order to examine the structure, relation of parts etc.
To analyze in minute detail.
examples: Before applying their proposed solution, we need to dissect each part.
She hated dissecting the samples in her biology class.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word dis + secare meaning 'apart' + 'to cut.'
Dissect is to 'cut up something that is whole into parts' while separate is 'to create distance from one to another.'

meanings: Made conspicuous by excellence.
Having an air of dignity or eminence.
examples: Please welcome our distinguished alumni and celebrated faculty.
He is a distinguished member of the community who is liked by everyone.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word dis + stinguere meaning 'apart' + 'put out.'
Distinguished implies 'fame or being unique because of excellence or achievement.'

meanings: The quality of being holy.
Religious studies.
examples: They persuaded him to study mathematics instead of divinity.
Most religions center on worshipping divinity.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word divinus meaning 'belonging to a deity.'
Its root word divine implies holiness and goodness.

meanings: To disclose or reveal.
examples: The accused is required by the court to divulge all information about the case.
She was surprised by the secrets divulged by her friend.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word dis + vulgare meaning 'apart' + 'make common property.'
Divulge implies revelation of something that is previously unknown or secret.

meanings: Relating to any strong set of principles concerning faith, morals, etc.
Asserting opinions in a rigid or arrogant manner.
examples: It is common to hear dogmatic arguments from opposite political parties.
I refuse to argue with someone who is so dogmatic.
further_information: Originated from the Greek word dokein meaning 'to seem good or think.'
Being dogmatic stems from the belief that one's opinion is absolute and accurate.

meanings: Something that is sorrowful or mournful.
examples: Why does she have a doleful look on her face?
The failure of the project put him in a doleful mood.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word dolere meaning 'suffer or grieve.'
The synonym depressing implies a more negative emotion.

meanings: Of or relating to the home, the household, household affairs, or the family; Something produced or manufactured in one's own country. (adj.)
A person paid to help with cleaning and other household chores. (n.)
examples: Playing board games with the family is such a domestic pleasure. (adj.)
All the cleaning was undertaken by the domestic. (n.)
further_information: Originated from the Latin word domus meaning 'house.'
Domestic can also be used to refer to something that is within a territory or a country.

meanings: To be dull or cheerless.
Any of several fabrics of light greyish-brown color, especially of thick wool or cotton.
examples: Why do you always wear that drab grey shirt that looks so boring?
A young man dressed in drabs.
further_information: Originated from the Old French word drap meaning 'cloth.'
Drab is similar to boring.

meanings: The initial or preliminary version of a drawing, document or design.
To create the initial version of a drawing, document or design.
examples: My first draft of the essay was very basic and more work was required.
Draft your ideas and submit them by tomorrow afternoon.
further_information: Originated from the Old Norse word drattr meaning 'to draw.'
Draft may be confused with Draught which sounds the same but means 'a current of air.'

meanings: To wet thoroughly.
A dose of medicine administered to an animal.
examples: The rain was so sudden that we were drenched.
The veterinarian administered a worming drench to the cows.
further_information: Originated from the Germanic word drenc meaning 'drink or draft.'
Drench means to 'make very wet' whereas flood means 'a (usually disastrous) overflow of water.'

meanings: To become smaller and smaller.
examples: I didn't notice that the candies in the jar dwindled to almost nothing.
Due to excessive rainfall and flooding, the crops dwindled and failed.
further_information: Originated from the Middle English dwinen meaning 'waste away or fade.'
Should not be confused with dindle which means 'to tingle or vibrate, such as a loud sound does.'

meanings: Serious in intention, purpose, or effort.
Full seriousness, as of intention or purpose.
examples: John is known to be an earnest worker and an honest person.
You need to speak in earnest to be taken seriously.
further_information: Originated from the Old Norse ern meaning 'able or vigorous.'
Earnest is commonly misspelled as ernest which is a male name.

meanings: A flowing backward or away.
To flow back or away, as the water of a tide.
examples: The ebb of the once great culture can be seen in the old dilapidated structures.
The water is ebbing towards the sea in a slow, hypnotic manner.
further_information: Originated from the Old English ebba meaning 'falling of the tide.'
Ebb and flow are 'two phases of the tide or any similar movement of water.'

meanings: Frugality in the expenditure or consumption of money, materials, etc.; Management of the resources of a community, country, etc.
Costing less to make, buy, or operate.
examples: He attempted to combine good living with economy.
Could I book an economy car for the trip?
further_information: Originated from the Greek words oikos and nemein meaning 'house' and 'manage.'
Economy may also refer to 'the management of financial and other resources of a group or area.'

meanings: Uncanny, so as to inspire superstitious fear.
examples: I'm not happy that we are in an eerie forest at night.
Hearing a midnight owl hoot is quite eerie and creepy.
further_information: Originated from the Old Frisian word erg meaning 'evil or bad.'
Can also be spelled as eery.

meanings: (Of a liquid) Giving off bubbles of gas.
examples: This mineral water is quite effervescent and gives off a strong smell.
The perfume that you just bought is very effervescent.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word ex + fervescere meaning 'out' + 'begin to boil.'
An effervescent personality means someone who is lively and enthusiastic.

meanings: Tastefully fine or luxurious in dress, style, design, etc.
Gracefully refined and dignified, as in tastes, habits, or literary style.
examples: An elegant young gentleman just arrived, greeting everyone in the party.
The design of the building is quite elegant and sophisticated.
further_information: Originated from the Latin elegans meaning 'dainty, fastidious.'
Elegant may refer to behavior, taste, or style.

meanings: The practice or art of using language with fluency and aptness.
examples: The candidate showed his eloquence during the elections.
A certain level of eloquence takes time and effort to perfect.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word ex + loqui meaning 'out' + 'to speak.'
Eloquence often refers to the ability to speak well in public.

meanings: An order of a government prohibiting trade or other commercial activity.
To impose an embargo on.
examples: There was an announcement of embargo due to the storm.
Due to the sudden announcement, many ships were embargoed.
further_information: Originated from in + barra meaning 'within' + 'a bar.'
Embargo is only used for commercial activity whereas ban is a general term for restriction.

meanings: To beautify by adding decorative details or features.
examples: The cake is embellished with colorful candies and tasty marshmallows.
Do not embellish your speech too much, as it can get boring.
further_information: Originated from the Latin bellus meaning 'handsome or pretty.'
In literature, embellish means 'to enhance by adding fine details.'

meanings: To appropriate fraudulently to one's own use, such as money or property entrusted to one's care.
examples: They found out about the plan to embezzle the company funds.
The thieves embezzled a large amount of money.
further_information: Originated from the Old French word em + besillier meaning 'into' + 'torment or destroy.'
Embezzlement is a type of stealing by misappropriating or misusing money.

meanings: Identification with the feelings, thoughts, or attitudes of others.
examples: Mary is empathetic to the situation of the victims of the disaster.
The children like talking to the empathetic counsellor.
further_information: Originated from the Greek word in + pathos meaning 'in' + 'feeling.'
Empathetic means 'putting yourself in the shoes of another' whereas sympathetic means 'feeling sorrow for hardships of another.'

meanings: To encipher or encode.
examples: Make sure that your files are encrypted before transferring them.
This software will encrypt your messages before sending them.
further_information: Originated from the Greek word en + kruptos meaning 'in' + 'hidden.'
Encryption involves creating a hidden message or information.

meanings: To approve, support, or sustain.
examples: This bakery must be good for it to be endorsed by a celebrity.
The report was endorsed by the college.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word in + dorsum meaning 'in or on' + 'back.'
In Law, endorse means 'to sign one's name on (a commercial document or other instrument).' It may also be spelled as indorse.

meanings: To be lasting or permanent.
examples: His work has an enduring effect on people which makes him memorable.
The successful businessman formed enduring relationships with his customers.
further_information: Originated from the Latin in + durus meaning 'in' + 'hard.'
Enduring may also mean 'suffer patiently.'

meanings: To produce, cause, or give rise to.
examples: A heart full of hate engenders prejudice and inspires violence.
The restaurant is giving away free dessert to engender interest from potential customers.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word in + generare meaning 'in' + 'generate.'
Should not be confused with endanger meaning 'to expose to danger.'
