meanings: To swallow up; To surround completely.
To plunge or immerse.
examples: The disastrous tsunami engulfed many villages and towns in its path.
There's an upcoming test, so he engulfed himself in studies.
further_information: Originated from the 1500s' word en + gulf meaning 'put in' + 'gulf.'
Engulfed has similar meaning to the phrasal verbs swallow up, soak up, and suck in.

meanings: A feeling or condition of hostility.
examples: The competing teams showed enmity towards one another.
Enmity is easily solved by open communication and compromise.
further_information: Originated from the Old French word enemite meaning 'hostile feeling.'
The exact opposite of enmity is amity meaning 'friendship.'

meanings: An event or activity that happens after something else, often as a result of it.
examples: They tried a risky solution which was the cause of the ensuing problems the next day.
The storm was terrifying, and the ensuing wreckage took months to clear.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word sequi meaning 'follow.'
Ensuing is a result of a previous event while following is a general term for 'what comes next.'

meanings: Holding one's attention completely.
examples: The enthralling performance earned a standing ovation.
She was quite an enthralling conversationalist.
further_information: Originated from Old English en + thrall meaning 'to put in' + 'a person who is in bondage.'
Enthralling implies 'something interesting enough to hold one's complete attention' while thrilling means 'causing feeling of sudden excitement.'

meanings: Full of or characterized by interest or excitement.
examples: He is very enthusiastic about his new job.
An enthusiastic child showed interest in participating in class.
further_information: Originated from the Greek word enthous meaning 'possessed by a god.'
An older usage means 'to a person possessed by a god, or someone who exhibited intense piety.'

meanings: To mention separately, as in counting.
examples: Can you enumerate the supplies that we will need for the trip?
The teacher enumerated four objectives for the year.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word ex + numerus meaning 'out' + 'number.'
Should not be confused with remunerate meaning 'to pay, recompense, or reward for work, trouble, etc.'

meanings: A particular period of time marked by distinctive features, events, etc.
examples: The popularity of streaming websites and applications marks the end of the epoch of the DVD format.
The Renaissance is an epoch of innovation and transformation.
further_information: Originated from the Greek word epi + echein meaning 'on' + 'to hold.'
Should not be confused with epic meaning 'noting or pertaining to a long poetic composition.'

meanings: Of, relating to, or resembling a horse. (adj.)
A horse. (n.)
examples: There is an ongoing equine flu outbreak in the county during the winter. (adj.)
That is a beautiful equine in your farm. Is it for sale? (n.)
further_information: Originated from the Latin word equus meaning 'horse.'
Equine is for horses, as feline is for cats and canine is for dogs.

meanings: Allowing the possibility of several different meanings, as a word or phrase.
examples: The equivocal statements of politicians often confuse the public.
The instruction was too equivocal; that's why I failed to solve the problem.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word aequus + vocare meaning 'equally' + 'to call.'
The exact opposite of equivocal is unequivocal meaning 'absolute or clear.'

meanings: To go astray in thought or belief.
To make a mistake.
examples: To err is human; to forgive, divine.
I accidentally erred when calculating my tax and had to redo everything.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word errare meaning 'to stray.'
Should not be confused with error which means 'deviation from accuracy or correctness.'

meanings: A short and quick trip to accomplish a specific purpose.
examples: I'm swamped with errands today; I can't rest.
I reduce my errands on weekends by going to the grocery store after work.
further_information: Originated from the Old English word ærende meaning 'message or mission.'
Errand implies 'short and easy task.'

meanings: Deviating from the usual or proper course in conduct or opinion.
examples: She was showing erratic behavior during her shift at work.
Observe if a car is driving in an erratic manner and report to me immediately.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word errare meaning 'to stray or err.'
Erratic implies 'inconsistent and unpredictable.'

meanings: Pertaining to or characteristic of a people, especially a group.
examples: Pupils from a wide variety of ethnic backgrounds study in the school.
The ethnic minority is requesting protection from people encroaching upon their lands.
further_information: Originated from the Greek word ethnos meaning 'nation.'
The related word indigenous means 'born or native to a land or region' while ethnic means 'relating to a group.'

meanings: To show clearly; make evident or manifest.
examples: His letters evince the excitement he felt at winning the trophy.
It was exciting to see children evince an interest in science.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word ex + vincere meaning 'out' + 'to overcome.'
The adjective form evincible which means 'to show clearly' should not be confused with invincible which means 'something which cannot be defeated.'

meanings: To increase the severity, bitterness, or violence of.
examples: Touching a burned skin will exacerbate the pain and infection.
The statement given by the president will exacerbate the tense relationship with other countries.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word ex + acerbus meaning 'out' + 'harsh or bitter.'
In Medicine, exacerbation means 'the worsening of a disease or an increase in its symptoms.'

meanings: To make hollow by removing the inner part.
To dig or scoop out (earth, sand, etc.).
examples: They are planning to excavate a site where ancient potteries were found.
The city government requires a permit if you want to excavate near a busy street.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word cavus meaning 'hollow.'
In archaeology, excavation, which is the noun form of excavate, is the exposure, processing and recording of archaeological remains.

meanings: To clear, as of an accusation.
To relieve, as from an obligation, duty, or task.
examples: The judge is about to exonerate an innocent man.
He's waiting for his manager to exonerate him from his duties so he can go home early.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word ex + onus meaning 'from' + 'a burden.'
Exonerate is typically used in proceedings with the law.

meanings: Exceeding the bounds of custom, propriety, or reason, especially in amount or extent.
examples: Minnie was surprised at the exorbitant fee from the bank.
I'm trying not to make any exorbitant purchases because of my budget.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word ex + orbita meaning 'out from' + 'course or track.'
Should not be confused with exuberant meaning 'full of vitality.'

meanings: Characterized by promptness.
examples: The assistant provided an expeditious answer to the questions from the managers.
Fast food staff are used to providing expeditious and professional service.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word ex + pedis meaning 'out' + 'fetter or chain for feet.'
Expeditious implies 'efficient but careful' whereas hasty implies 'moving in speed or hurried manner.'

meanings: Of great extent.
examples: They are planning to go on an extensive travel around Europe.
The storm covered an extensive area over Scotland.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word ex + tendere meaning 'out' + 'to stretch.'
Extensive may be misspelled as extentive which is not a word.

meanings: To infer (an unknown) from something that is known.
examples: Data collected from one school cannot be extrapolated to all schools.
The figures were extrapolated from past trends.
further_information: The word was coined in 1862 by combining extra + interpolate meaning 'outside' + 'to introduce (something additional or extraneous) between other things or parts.'
In Mathematics, extrapolate means 'extend (a graph, curve, or range of values) by inferring unknown values from trends in the known data.'

meanings: Spending much more than is necessary or wise.
Exceeding the bounds of reason, as actions, demands, opinions, or passions.
examples: He is known to be an extravagant fellow who spends a lot of money on unnecessary things.
This restaurant is a little too extravagant for my taste.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word extra + vagari meaning 'outside' + 'wander.'
Extravagant has a more negative connotation than excessive.

meanings: State of being overly excited, joyful and happy.
examples: Jan's exuberance is definitely catching and inspiring.
The wild exuberance of the dancers was loved by the audience.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word uber meaning 'fertile.'
Exuberance is often confused in usage with its adjective form: exuberant.

meanings: Containing falsehood or deception.
examples: Always observe fallacious statements during debates.
The government may be victim to fallacious testimonies.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word fallacia meaning 'deceive.'
Fallacious connotes 'intent to deceive.'

meanings: A person with an extreme and uncritical enthusiasm or zeal, as in religion or politics.
examples: Sam considers himself a fitness fanatic and runs every single day.
The posters on your wall show that you're a fanatic supporter of the sports club.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word fanum meaning 'temple.'
Fanatic implies 'extreme devotion' compared to enthusiast which means 'a person who is interested in something.'

meanings: Motivated or characterized by an extreme, uncritical enthusiasm or zeal, as in religion or politics.
examples: The fanatical crowd cheered for their candidate.
When Mike was a teenager, he was a fanatical soccer fan.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word fanum meaning 'temple.'
Just like its noun form, fanatic, fanatical implies 'extreme devotion.'

meanings: Excessively particular, critical, or demanding.
Requiring or characterized by excessive care or delicacy.
examples: Some children prove to be fastidious eaters, demanding specific food.
His boss is quite fastidious which adds to his worries and stress.
further_information: Evolved from two Latin words fastus + taedium meaning 'contempt or arrogance' + 'aversion or disgust.'
Fastidious implies 'extreme attention to detail.'

meanings: A narrow opening produced by cleavage or separation of parts.
examples: They discovered a fissure on their way down the mountain.
The earthquake created a fissure in the middle of the town.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word findere meaning 'to split.'
A fissure is slightly bigger than a crack.

meanings: Adapted or suited. (adj.)
Fix or put (something) into place. (v.)
A sudden uncontrollable outbreak of intense emotion, laughter, coughing, or other action or activity. (n.)
examples: Jean fits the senior manager position. (adj.)
Wait until the seamstress fits you in a dress. (v.)
She was in fits of laughter after watching the man slip. (n.)
further_information: Observed in the mid-15th century meaning 'suited to the circumstances, proper.'
In Athletics, fit means 'someone who is physically capable.'

meanings: Strikingly bold or brilliant.
Conspicuously dashing and colorful.
examples: His flamboyant performance earned a high score from the judges.
Jimmy loves buying flamboyant cars and motorcycles.
further_information: Originated from the French word flambe meaning 'a flame.'
Flamboyant implies 'something that is noticeable and obvious.'

meanings: A soft, slightly napped fabric of wool or wool and another fiber, used for trousers, jackets, shirts, etc.
examples: He mostly wears flannel trousers because of their comfort.
Flannel shirts are usually popular during autumn because of their colors.
further_information: Originated from the Welsh word gwlan meaning 'wool.'
Flannel is a type of cloth usually patterned with black and another color.

meanings: Given or inclined to amorous behavior.
examples: Her flirtatious smile is quite beautiful and endearing.
The guy becomes flirtatious when the girls are around him.
further_information: Originated from the 1500s' word flirt meaning 'joke or jest.'
Flirtatious is sometimes used informally as flirt or flirty.

meanings: A retailer of flowers, ornamental plants, etc.
examples: The florist suggested a bouquet of roses for my girlfriend.
During wedding season, the florist is very busy delivering centerpieces.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word flos + ist meaning 'flower' + 'one who does or makes.'
A florist is usually a business person while a floral designer focuses on design.

meanings: Wave something to attract attention.
To grow luxuriantly, or thrive in growth, as a plant.
examples: The trees we planted last year flourished because of your care.
The waitress served our food with flourish and flash.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word flos meaning 'flower.'
Flourish may also mean 'to succeed or achieve something.'

meanings: Covered with or having many flowers.
(Of speech or writing) Full of elaborate words and phrases.
examples: The garden is flowery this time of the year with roses, tulips, and other beautiful blooms.
She convinced them with flowery words and radiant smile.
further_information: Originated from the 1200s' word flowre + -y meaning 'flower' + 'full of or characterized by.'
Flowery is also a direct synonym of floral.

meanings: The leaves of a plant, collectively.
The representation of leaves, flowers, and branches in paintings, architectural ornaments, etc.
examples: The foliage in the garden is getting too thick. Can you trim it a bit?
The statue is decorated with realistic foliage created by skilled artists.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word folium meaning 'leaf.'
A less popular synonym for foliage is leafage.

meanings: The crime of falsely making or altering a writing by which the legal rights or obligations of another person are apparently affected.
examples: He was falsely accused of forgery by his former boss.
Forgery is considered a felony in most parts of the world.
further_information: Originated from the Old French word forge + ery meaning 'smithy' + 'place for.'
Forgery implies 'a few copied objects' while counterfeit implies 'a large number of copies.'

meanings: Desolate or dreary.
Expressive of hopelessness.
examples: The old house looks very forlorn without the family in it.
I hate leaving every morning because my puppy looks forlorn.
further_information: Originated from the Old English word for + leosan meaning 'completely' + 'to lose.'
Depressed implies heavier emotion than forlorn.

meanings: Going straight to the point.
examples: It is quite a balance to be forthright and polite.
The student was forthright in admitting that he forgot to do his homework.
further_information: Originated from the Old English word forth + right meaning 'forward' + 'morally correct.'
Forthright means 'being straight and honest' while candid implies 'impartial and free from prejudice' and offensive means 'causing resentful displeasure.'

meanings: To protect or strengthen against attack.
To furnish with a means of resisting force or withstanding strain or wear.
examples: The girl was fortified by her faith and managed to cope with her difficulties successfully.
The palace is fortified with stonewalls and wide moats.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word fortis meaning 'strong.'
Fortified can also mean 'to make something better,' as in breakfast cereals fortified with vitamins.

meanings: Characterized by lack of seriousness or sense.
Self-indulgently carefree.
examples: His suggestions were frivolous and were ignored by the team.
Jamie's friend did not believe her frivolous apology and dismissed her.
further_information: Originated from the Middle French word fricare meaning 'to rub.'
Frivolous implies 'not having any serious purpose or value' whereas the related word facetious means 'treating serious issues with deliberately inappropriate humor.'

meanings: Serving as, or being an essential part of, a foundation or basis.
A basic principle, rule, law, or the like, that serves as the groundwork of a system.
examples: The government is required to protect our fundamental rights.
The fundamentals of mathematics include arithmetic.
further_information: Originated from the Old French word fundare meaning 'to found.'
Fundamentals imply 'building blocks of something more advanced.'

meanings: Incapable of producing any result.
examples: His efforts proved to be futile which frustrated him even more.
All defenses proved futile when the enemy attacked.
further_information: Originated from the Middle French word futilis meaning 'vain or worthless.'
Not to be confused with fertile which means 'productive.'

meanings: Crude or tastelessly colorful, showy, or elaborate, as with clothes or decoration.
examples: She wore garish clothes and obnoxious jewelry.
They wore silly hats in garish colors.
further_information: Originated from the Old Norse word gaurr meaning 'rough fellow.'
Not to be confused with garnish which means 'to decorate (especially food).'

meanings: Any article of clothing.
examples: It is difficult to choose the correct garment to wear for a special party.
I wore a waterproof outer garment in the rain.
further_information: Originated from the Old French word garnir meaning 'equip.'
Garment generally refers to one item of clothing, whereas attire refers to all that one is wearing.

meanings: Shockingly frightful or dreadful.
Extremely unwell.
examples: He had a ghastly look to his face after visiting the horror house.
Jimmy is still sick and that's why he looks ghastly and thin.
further_information: Originated from the Old English word gast meaning 'ghost.'
Terrifying implies a stronger emotion than ghastly.

meanings: An open space in a forest.
examples: The glade is a perfect place to set up camp for the night.
The boy scouts were tasked to find the glade in the forest.
further_information: Originated from the Old Norse word glædr meaning 'bright.'
Glen is a secluded narrow valley compared to glade which is a clearing.

meanings: Readily fluent, often thoughtlessly, superficially, or insincerely so.
examples: Do not be glib about such a horrible tragedy.
The manager is annoyed by his glib questions and tasteless remarks.
further_information: Originated from the Low German word glibberig meaning 'smooth or slippery.'
Glib may also mean 'being talkative without careful thought.'

meanings: To feed or fill to excess.
An excessive supply or amount.
examples: On weekends, I like to glut on ice cream and chocolate chip cookies.
There is a recent glut of superhero films from popular comic books.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word glutire meaning 'to swallow.'
A more popular noun is glutton which means 'a person who eats and drinks excessively.'

meanings: To grind or strike (the teeth) together, especially in rage or pain.
To bite with grinding teeth.
examples: The hungry lions gnashed their teeth and lunged at the bars of the enclosure.
He decided to gnash his teeth than say something mean.
further_information: Originated from the Danish word knaske meaning 'crush with the teeth.'
Gnash is different from gnaw which means 'to repeatedly bite something tough.'

meanings: To scoop out or hollow out.
examples: The sculpture was gouged out incorrectly which made the artist very upset.
They tunnel was gouged out of the mountain.
further_information: Originated from the Welsh word gyflin meaning 'beak.'
A gouge is a curved blade while chisel is a flat blade.

meanings: A person charged with the direction or control of an institution, society, etc.
examples: The governor is looking forward to his first official project as a public servant.
A new governor will be elected based on a popular vote next week.
further_information: Originated from the Greek word kybernān meaning 'to steer or pilot a ship.'
The word governor is gender neutral but, sometimes, the word governess is used for a female governor.

meanings: Fond of the company of others.
examples: He is so gregarious that he becomes the life of the party.
A gregarious person usually has many friends and acquaintances.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word grex meaning 'a flock.'
Gregarious implies 'outgoing and comfortable with others' while affable means 'friendly and courteous.'

meanings: To humble oneself or act in an abject manner, as in great fear or utter servility.
To lie or crawl with the face downward, especially in humility, fear, etc.
examples: He was so ashamed that he had to grovel and ask for favors from strangers.
Do not grovel if it is not your fault or your responsibility.
further_information: Originated from the Old Norse grufla meaning 'to grovel or crouch down.'
Should not be confused with gravel meaning 'small stones and pebbles, or a mixture of these with sand.'

meanings: Displaying or reflecting reluctance or unwillingness.
examples: Smith's grudging acceptance of his loss is very obvious.
The student offered a grudging apology to the teacher.
further_information: Originated from the same word in the 15th century meaning 'to murmur or complain.'
Similar to begrudging which means 'to envy someone or to give something resentfully.'

meanings: Insidious cunning in attaining a goal; crafty or artful deception.
examples: Most politicians take advantage of their guile to convince people.
Your guile will not work with your teacher anymore.
further_information: Originated from the Frankish word wiglia meaning 'trick or ruse.'
Guile is related but not similar to beguile which means 'to charm or enchant (someone), sometimes in a deceptive way.'

meanings: Made commonplace or trite.
examples: He used the same excuse all the time and eventually it became hackneyed.
Some movies have hackneyed plots but people still watch them.
further_information: Evolved from the figurative use of the English word hackney meaning 'use a horse for riding.'
Hackneyed implies 'overused' while jaded implies 'weariness.'

meanings: Regarded as holy or sacred.
examples: The locals consider the forest as hallowed grounds.
The church is taking care of hallowed objects for their cultural and historical value.
further_information: Originated from the Greek word hieros meaning 'sacred or divine.'
Should not be confused with hollowed meaning 'having a space or cavity inside.'

meanings: Undecided, doubtful, or disinclined.
examples: Donna is hesitant to present her findings to the academic panel.
I'm hesitant to tell him that he made a mistake because he's my boss.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word haesitare meaning 'to stick fast and stammer.'
Hesitant implies 'unsure but willing' while reluctant means 'unsure but unwilling.'

meanings: To raise or lift, especially by some mechanical appliance.
An apparatus for hoisting, as a block and tackle, a derrick, or a crane.
examples: I really don't know how to hoist this couch to the second floor.
I think the hoist holding the flag is broken.
further_information: Originated from the Old Norse word hissa upp meaning 'raise.'
Hoist implies 'raising something using a machine' while lift is a general term for 'moving to a higher place.'

meanings: Causing horror or fear.
examples: There was a horrific accident across town which caused heavy traffic.
Performing in front of the crowd is not horrific after all.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word horrere meaning 'tremble or shudder.'
Should not be confused with honorific meaning 'conveying honor.'

meanings: Not proud or arrogant.
To lower in condition, importance, or dignity.
examples: He is known to be a humble fellow with a big heart.
After such actions, he humbled himself to regain trust from people.
further_information: Originated from the Latin humilis meaning 'lowly or humble.'
Being humble means 'acknowledging one's strength while being comfortable with another's authority' while modest means 'not showing off.'

meanings: Containing a high amount of water or water vapor.
examples: The weather is very humid when it's cloudy and the temperature is high.
It's usually humid in tropical areas during summer.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word humere meaning 'be moist.'
Humid is the 'presence of water in the air' while hot implies 'high temperature.'

meanings: About to happen.
Imminently threatening or menacing.
examples: I feel like there's an impending danger in this trip.
There is an impending storm from the south as evident from the dark clouds.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word in + pendere meaning 'forward' + 'hang.'
Should not be confused with pending meaning 'awaiting decision.'

meanings: That which cannot be penetrated, pierced, entered, etc.
Inaccessible to ideas, influences, etc.
examples: The castle is practically impenetrable thanks to the walls and the cavalry.
His confidence is impenetrable even during difficult times.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word in + penetrabilis meaning 'opposite of' + 'penetrable.'
Impenetrable implies 'that which cannot be penetrated from the outside' while impregnable means 'unable to be defeated.'

meanings: Absolutely necessary or required.
A command.
examples: It is imperative to clean up after using the gymnasium.
It is an imperative to keep good relationships among nations.
further_information: Originated from the Late Latin word in + parare meaning 'toward' + 'make ready.'
Should not be confused with imperial meaning 'pertaining to an empire.'

meanings: Domineering in a haughty manner.
Urgent or needed.
examples: The president has an imperious manner which intimidates his staff.
The Queen raised her hand in an imperious manner and signalled the end of discussion.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word in + parare meaning 'in' + 'to order or prepare.'
Should not be confused with impervious meaning 'not permitting penetration or passage.'

meanings: Of, relating to, or characterized by sudden or rash action, emotion, etc.
examples: He regretted his impetuous decision to buy a sports car.
It's easy to be impetuous when you're young and carefree.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word in + petere meaning 'into' + 'aim for.'
Being impetuous implies carelessness.

meanings: To be mischievous.
Acting in a childish way like a rascal.
examples: Do not act like an impish child and wreak havoc during class.
His impish attitude is quite adorable but sometimes annoying.
further_information: Originated from the Old English impa + ish meaning 'young shoot' + 'native of something.'
Impish implies 'doing naughty things for fun' while mischievous implies 'being troublesome.'

meanings: To show someone to be involved in a crime.
examples: The witness implicated an innocent person in the crime.
He had been implicated in a financial scandal.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word in + plicare meaning 'into' + 'to fold.'
Implicate implies 'involving something that results in consequence' while imply means 'conveying something without explicitly stating it.'

meanings: To beg urgently or piteously for (aid, mercy, pardon, etc.).
examples: They implored him to work for the company after he showed how skillful he was.
The beggar implored for a little change so he could eat.
further_information: Originated from the Middle French word in + plorare meaning 'upon' + 'to weep or cry out.'
A variant spelling is emplore.

meanings: Something unintentional.
Of, relating to, or characterized by lack of attention.
examples: An inadvertent blessing came to the family in the form of three puppies.
The microwave is an inadvertent invention which resulted in a successful business.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word in + advertentia meaning 'not' + 'to direct one's attention.'
Inadvertent implies 'resulting from something unplanned' whereas accident means 'an unfortunate incident.'

meanings: Not attentive; negligent.
examples: After more than four hours of class, I become inattentive because of tiredness.
It is difficult to teach inattentive students especially when the topic is not that interesting.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word in + attendere meaning 'opposite of' + 'give heed to.'
Inattentive means 'to lose interest' while distracted implies 'inability to focus.'

meanings: Not defined; not precisely fixed in extent.
examples: Mark spent an indeterminate amount of money in the festival looking for interesting dishes to try.
There is an indeterminate number of birds feeding in the park.
further_information: Originated from the Late Latin in + determinatus meaning 'not' + 'limited.'
In Mathematics, indeterminate means 'something whose value is not specified.'

meanings: Absolutely necessary, essential, or requisite.
A person or thing that is indispensable.
examples: Everyone in the team is indispensable because of their expertise.
The textbook is an indispensable part of learning.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word in + dispensabilis meaning 'opposite of' + 'disburse or administer.'
Indispensable is commonly misspelled as indispensible.

meanings: To yield to an inclination or desire.
To yield to, satisfy, or gratify (desires, feelings, etc.).
examples: I sometimes indulge in an extra serving of dessert when I’m feeling down.
Janet sometimes indulges in luxury spending like buying jewelry and bags.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word indulgere meaning 'to give free reign to.'
Indulge may imply 'to fully follow one's desire.'

meanings: Working energetically and devotedly; hard-working.
examples: Johnny is known to be a very industrious and smart worker.
If you are industrious enough, you can finish college in three years instead of four.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word in + struere meaning 'within' + 'to build.'
Should not be confused with industrial meaning 'of, pertaining to, of the nature of, or resulting from industry.'

meanings: Unfit to be eaten.
examples: Make sure that you're not collecting inedible mushrooms or else we’ll get poisoned.
Jan put so much hot sauce in her dish that it has become inedible.
further_information: Originated from the Late Latin word in + edibilis meaning 'opposite of' + 'eatable.'
Inedible is commonly misspelled as unedible.

meanings: Unable to be avoided, evaded, or escaped from.
examples: Getting old is something inevitable that we all have to face.
Global warming becomes inevitable as we continue ignoring it.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word in + evitare meaning 'not' + 'avoid.'
The synonym imminent implies stronger emotion as it connotes 'looming or threatening.'

meanings: Existing in someone or something as a permanent and inseparable element, quality, or attribute.
examples: His inherent creativity allowed him to apply for art school.
Despite his inherent fear of mathematics, he worked hard to get straight A's.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word in + harere meaning 'in' + 'to stick.'
Inherent implies 'something that comes naturally' while intrinsic implies 'something that can be acquired.'

meanings: Not harmful or injurious.
Not likely to irritate or offend.
examples: Drinking lemon tea when you have a cold is an innocuous home remedy.
Lea makes sure that she appears innocuous and polite.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word in + nocuss meaning 'not' + 'injurious.'
Should not be confused with innocent meaning 'free from moral wrong.'

meanings: To cover, line, or separate with a material that prevents or reduces the passage, transfer, or leakage of heat, electricity, or sound.
examples: The rubber coating insulates the wires to prevent short circuits.
Sometimes, Jan insulates herself from a situation to avoid becoming emotional.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word insula + ate meaning 'island' + a verb forming suffix.
Similar to isolated meaning 'to set apart from a group.'

meanings: Incapable of being surmounted, passed over, or overcome.
examples: Sometimes, problems seem insurmountable when you’re stressed out.
He overcame insurmountable situations to succeed in life.
further_information: Originated from the 1600s' French word in + sur + monter meaning 'opposite' + 'beyond' + 'to go up.'
Insurmountable is commonly misspelled as unsurmoutable.

meanings: To bring together or incorporate (parts) into a whole.
To make up, combine, or complete to produce a whole or a larger unit.
examples: It was a bit challenging to integrate into the new neighborhood.
You need to integrate the result of your first and second experiment.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word in + tangere meaning 'not' + 'to touch.'
Integrate implies 'incorporating an individual to a group' while assimilate means 'to adopt the ways of another culture or group.'

meanings: Adherence to moral and ethical principles; soundness of moral character; honesty.
examples: Lewis tries to live with integrity every day.
Integrity is sometimes hard to find in people these days.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word in + tangere meaning 'not' + 'to touch.'
Integrity implies 'adherence to a standard' while virtue is having 'high moral standards.'

meanings: Stopping or ceasing for a time; alternately ceasing and beginning again.
examples: The power kept going off intermittently during the storm.
They intermittently see each other during the week.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word inter + mittere meaning 'between' + 'let go.'
Intermittently implies 'stopping and starting at intervals' while sporadically means 'rare and scattered in occurrence.'

meanings: An intervening period of time.
A space between things, points, limits, etc.
examples: The interval between semesters can be used to work part-time.
The rapids have short intervals of still water.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word inter + vallum meaning 'between' + 'rampart.'
Interval is often used to refer to time and space.

meanings: A shy person.
A mark of introversion.
To turn inward.
examples: He's naturally an introvert, so he loves to stay at home and relax.
His introvert nature makes it hard for him to socialize during parties.
Sometimes I have to introvert my thoughts before speaking out.
further_information: Originated from the Modern Latin word intro + vertere meaning 'to the inside' + 'to turn.'
Introvert implies 'preference for quiet environment' while shy means 'fear of negative judgment.'

meanings: To give vigor to; fill with life and energy.
examples: The rain invigorated the otherwise dry soil, so the plants grew.
He felt invigorated from drinking lemonade after playing under the hot sun.
further_information: Originated from the 1600s' word in + vigor + ate meaning 'opposite of' + 'energy in activity' + verbal suffix.

meanings: To call for with earnest desire.
To declare to be binding in effect.
examples: The leader invoked the support of all the team members.
Any citizen can invoke their rights as stated in the country's constitution.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word in + vocare meaning 'upon' + 'to call.'
Should not be confused with evoke which means 'to draw forth to mind, usually feelings and emotions.'

meanings: Intense anger.
examples: Do not show your ire to the public as it can make them uncomfortable.
Make sure to finish all your tasks or you'll earn the ire of the manager.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word ira meaning 'anger.'
The synonyms wrath and fury evoke stronger emotions than ire.

meanings: Dulled or satiated by over-indulgence.
Worn out or wearied.
examples: It just the 3rd class and he already feels jaded.
The employee tried out new things to avoid feeling jaded.
further_information: Evolved from the Old Norse word jalda meaning 'horse.'
Jaded implies 'a combination of exhaustion and boredom.'

meanings: A short journey.
To make a short journey.
examples: Having a fun jaunt with your friends is always great.
My jaunt to the grocery store is usually uneventful.
further_information: Became popular in the 1500s and meant 'tire (a horse) by riding back and forth.'
Unrelated to the adjective jaunty which means 'having or expressing a lively, cheerful, and self-confident manner.'

meanings: To speak or shout derisively.
A rude or mocking remark.
examples: The home crowd jeered at the opponent during the game.
A lot of his coworkers did not appreciate his jeers during the meeting.
further_information: Originated from the 1500s' word gyr meaning 'deride or mock.'
Jeer implies 'loud negative remarks' while heckle implies 'harsh utterance in an attempt to find weakness.'

meanings: Hazard or risk of exposure to loss, harm, death, or injury.
examples: Cops put their lives in jeopardy on a daily basis.
Do not put yourself in jeopardy by taking a selfie on a cliff.
further_information: Originated from the Old French phrase ieu parti meaning 'evenly divided game.'
In Law, jeopardy means 'danger of being convicted and punished for a criminal offence.'

meanings: To be in harmony or accord.
To utter mocking or scoffing words.
examples: The new student jibed with the rest of the class quickly.
Frequent jibes, however gentle, can be very annoying.
further_information: Originated from the English word gybe meaning 'shift a sail or boom.'
Jibe can be spelled as gibe and jibb.

meanings: To place close together or side by side, typically in comparison.
examples: Juxtaposed against the sad tragedy are the stories of heroism.
The artist juxtaposed the beauty of colors and the elegance of white and black in his recent work.
further_information: Originated from the combination of the Latin word juxta and the French word poser which means 'next' + 'poser.'
Juxtaposed implies 'nearness between the objects' while comparison is 'to examine objects against each other.'

meanings: Lacking brilliance or radiance.
A lack of brilliance or vitality.
examples: There were no excuses for the team’s lackluster performance.
Due to slowing economy, the company’s profits were lackluster.
further_information: Originated from the Old English word lac and the Middle French word lustre meaning 'lack of' + 'gloss or radiance.'
Spelled as lacklustre in British English.

meanings: A prominent or conspicuous object on land that serves as a guide.
To declare (a building, site, etc.) a landmark.
examples: The valley is a known landmark in the area.
UNESCO landmarked many natural treasures.
further_information: Originated from the Old English word land + mearc meaning 'ground or soil' + 'boundary or sign.'
A landmark may also mean 'something significant, note-worthy, or important.' For example, 'A landmark achievement.'

meanings: Lacking in vigor or vitality.
Lacking in spirit or interest.
examples: Her languid reply tells me that she is not interested in traveling alone.
After a long day, the waiter moved in a languid manner.
further_information: Originated from the Middle French word languere meaning 'weak or fatigued.'
Languid implies 'lacking in energy due to exhaustion.'

meanings: To be or become weak or feeble.
examples: Jamie's project languished on his desk for weeks.
The plants languished and died from the drought.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word languere meaning 'be weak or faint.'
Should not be confused with languid meaning 'lacking in vigor or vitality.'

meanings: To praise.
examples: Sunny was lauded during her graduation for her academic achievements.
The new single was lauded by the music press.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word laus meaning 'praise.'
Should not be confused with loud meaning 'strongly audible.'

meanings: Of, relating to, or affected with sluggishness.
examples: The hot weather makes me lethargic and sleepy.
Walking all these flights of stairs make me lethargic and out of breath.
further_information: Originated from the Greek word lethargikos meaning 'drowsy.'
Lethargic implies 'sleepiness or drowsiness.'

meanings: To set free, as from imprisonment or bondage.
examples: South Sudan was liberated only recently, so it is a very young country.
I feel liberated after school when I can play football.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word liber meaning 'free.'
In Chemistry and Physics, liberate means 'release (gas, energy, etc.) as a result of chemical reaction or physical decomposition.'

meanings: The act of setting someone free.
examples: A country's liberation is the start of the difficult journey to independence.
The citizens celebrated their liberation from the colonizers.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word liber meaning 'free.'

meanings: Full or suggestive of life or vital energy.
examples: I always enjoy the teacher's liveliness during a class.
Joanna's liveliness shows in her smile and laughter.
further_information: Originated from the Old English word lif + ly + ness meaning 'animated' + a suffix for adjectives.
Sometimes misspelled as liveliness which is not a word.

meanings: Accommodation in a house, especially in rooms for rent.
examples: Have you arranged our lodging for the camping trip?
This lodging is very luxurious with many high-end amenities.
further_information: Originated from the Old French word loge meaning 'hut.'
Lodging implies 'temporary home or house.'

meanings: Uncouth or aggressive man or boy. (n.)
To bow in respect. (v.)
examples: Sometimes, he can be such a lout when disturbed. (n.)
Everyone should lout once the queen passes by. (v.)
further_information: Originated from the Middle English word louten meaning 'bow down.'
Should not be confused with loot which means 'to rob.'

meanings: Profitable or money-making.
examples: They say business in real estate is very lucrative.
He is working hard to put up a business in the lucrative part of town.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word lucrum meaning 'gain or profit.'
Lucrative connotes 'gaining a lot with not much effort.'
Related word lucre means 'money/wealth.'

meanings: Gruesome; horrible.
Glaringly vivid or sensational.
examples: It was quite uncomfortable to hear the lurid details of the accident.
The lurid gossip is the talk of the town, but it is untrue.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word luro meaning 'wan or yellow.'
Lurid implies 'fine details or account' while vivid implies 'visual details.'

meanings: A civil officer charged with the administration of the law.
examples: The magistrate summoned the witnesses to the accident.
He is known to be a fair but strict magistrate.
further_information: Evolved from the Latin word magister meaning 'master.'
Magistrate is typically a public official.

meanings: Full of, characterized by, or showing ill-will; intentionally harmful.
examples: Do not believe all the malicious rumor going around town.
I'm not sure if he has malicious intent or he was just unaware of his actions.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word malus meaning 'bad or unpleasant.'
In Law, malicious means 'vicious, wanton, or mischievous in motivation or purpose.'
Other words with mal as a prefix are: Malaise, Malady, Maleficence, Malice etc. All of these words have a negative connotation.

meanings: To speak harmful untruths about. (v.)
Having or showing an evil disposition. (adj.)
examples: It is not honorable to malign another person. (v.)
The dark colors and dull furniture create a maligned atmosphere. (adj.)
further_information: Originated from the Latin word malus meaning 'bad.'
The adjective form of malign is malignant meaning 'disposed to cause harm, suffering, or distress deliberately.'

meanings: To treat or handle badly, cruelly, or roughly.
examples: The company is careful not to maltreat its employees.
You should never maltreat someone who is weaker than you.
further_information: Originated from the 1700s' word mal + treat meaning 'bad or ill' + 'action.'
Another form of maltreat is mistreat.

meanings: A large tent used for functions; A tall roof like projection above a theater entrance or gymnasium.
examples: The marquee was large enough to accommodate the whole team.
They welcomed the marquee player from the game.
further_information: Originated from the French word marquise meaning 'linen canopy over a tent.'
Should not be confused with marque meaning 'a product model or type, as of a luxury or racing car.'

meanings: A short note designating something to be remembered.
examples: We are still waiting for the president to sign the memorandum.
Have you read the memorandum about the new dress code?
further_information: Originated from the Latin word memor meaning 'mindful of.'
In Law, memorandum means 'a piece of writing, usually informal, containing the terms of a transaction.'

meanings: Having or showing no compassion; Cruel.
examples: The decision was quite merciless for me, as it was very strict.
Minny is considered a merciless debater because she can take on anyone.
further_information: Originated from the Middle English word merci + less meaning 'pity' + 'lacking/cannot be.'
Merciless connotes 'cruel attitude' while mean connotes 'to be unkind.'

meanings: Deserving praise, reward, esteem, etc.
examples: At such a young age, he has many meritorious achievements.
Even with a second place, his win still feels meritorious.
further_information: Originated from the Old French word merite + ous meaning 'wages, pay or reward' + suffix making adjectives.
Should not be confused with meretricious meaning 'alluring by a show of flashy or vulgar attractions.'

meanings: Taking or showing extreme care about minute details.
examples: It is fascinating to see her meticulous attention to detail.
The meticulous design gives an air of elegance to the statue.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word metus meaning 'fear.'
Meticulous means 'careful attention to detail' while fastidious means 'fussy about details.'

meanings: A yard or street lined by buildings originally used as stables but now often converted into dwellings.
examples: The house is located in a faraway mews outside the city limits.
She bought a mews house outside London to avoid the crowded streets.
further_information: Originated from the Old English word mæw meaning 'seagull.'
Mews can also mean 'the sound a cat makes.'

meanings: Very small.
A small or lower case letter.
examples: Even a minuscule donation can help the charity set up a scholarship program.
The old book is full of minuscules which can be very hard to read.
further_information: Originated from the Latin phrase minuscula littera meaning 'somewhat small letter.'
Minuscule is often misspelled as miniscule.

meanings: A person sent by a church into an area to carry on evangelism or other activities.
Pertaining to or connected with religious missions.
examples: The missionary visited different communities in the area.
The missionary work is very challenging but fulfilling.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word missio meaning 'act of sending.'
A missionary is not necessarily a member of the clergy.

meanings: To lessen in force or intensity, as wrath, grief, harshness, or pain.
To make less severe.
examples: There's no way to mitigate the errors made last week.
The team set up processes to mitigate possible emergencies.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word mitis meaning 'mild.'
Mitigate implies 'lessening harm' while alleviate means 'to make easier to endure.'

meanings: To soften in feeling or temper, as a person.
examples: A nice hot tea helps me mollify during stressful days.
Talking calmly can mollify an overexcited child when they're upset.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word mollis meaning 'soft.'
Mollify is to 'help soften a temper' while pacify means 'to restore peace.'

meanings: Of great or far-reaching importance or consequence.
examples: His graduation day is a momentous one for him after years of difficult study.
When the climbers finally reached the peak after many failed attempts, it was a momentous moment.
further_information: Originated from the mid-14th century word moment + ous meaning 'brief portion of time' + a suffix for adjectives.
Momentous evoke stronger emotions than important.

meanings: Lacking in variety; tediously unvarying.
A sound, continuing in one note.
examples: Sometimes, Sundays are quite monotonous when you have nothing planned.
His monotonous tone does not betray any emotion.
further_information: Originated from the Greek word monos + tonos meaning 'single or alone' + 'tone.'
Monotonic is a similar word and means 'speaking in an unchanged tone or pitch.'

meanings: Something erected in memory of a person, event, etc., such as a building, pillar, or statue.
To build a monument or monuments to; commemorate.
examples: The monument is being restored and soon will be open to the public.
This important event should be monumented for future generations.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word monere meaning 'remind.'
Monument implies 'efforts to preserve memory.'

meanings: To provide with a motive, or a cause or reason to act.
examples: It is imperative for a leader to motivate his/her followers.
Shane always tries to motivate himself even during difficult times.
further_information: Originated from the Old French word motif + ate meaning 'moving' + verbal suffix.
Motivate means 'to find reason for action' whereas inspire means 'to arouse positive feeling.'

meanings: (Of birds, insects, reptiles, etc.) To cast or shed the feathers, skin, or the like, that will be replaced by a new growth.
An act, process, or an instance of moulting/Something that is dropped in moulting.
examples: It is normal for some animals to look sickly while moulting.
The mountain goat is brilliant white after the autumn moult.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word mutare meaning 'to change.'
Moult is also spelled as molt.

meanings: A natural elevation of earth.
To form into a mound.
examples: You can see the river when you stand over that mound.
The soldiers will mound the eastern part of the camp to protect against enemies.
further_information: Originated from the Middle Dutch word mond meaning 'protection.'
Mound up the rice on a serving plate.

meanings: To wrap with something to deaden or prevent sound.
examples: The walls are muffled for the privacy of the tenants.
It is important for the ears to be muffled when working in a noisy environment.
further_information: Originated from the Old French word moufle meaning 'thick glove.'
A muffler is a part of a vehicle's exhaust system meant to reduce its noise.

meanings: Lacking excitement or interest; Of or relating to this world or earth as contrasted with heaven.
examples: Sometimes, mundane tasks are quite boring and repetitive.
On weekends, Jeanie likes to have mundane moments to relax and let her mind rest.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word mundus meaning 'world.'
Mundane implies 'unremarkable.'

meanings: Of or relating to ships of all kinds.
Belonging to, pertaining to, or connected with a navy.
examples: He is set to study naval engineering because he likes to work in ships.
Naval affairs are almost always confidential as required by the government.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word navis meaning 'ship.'
Should not be confused with navel which is a part of the human body.

meanings: A rounded, knotty depression in the center of a person's belly caused by the detachment of the umbilical cord after birth.
The central point or middle of anything or place.
examples: The umbilical cord is cut right at the navel when a baby is born.
An art museum is being constructed at the navel of the city.
further_information: Evolved from several sources such as Sanskrit nabhila, Prussian nabis, and Greek omphalos.
Should not be confused with naval which is 'anything related to sea-faring or ships.'

meanings: Hazy, vague, indistinct, or confused.
examples: Jimmy was so sleepy he had only a nebulous memory of the meeting.
A star cluster with large amount of gases is quite nebulous.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word nebula meaning 'mist.'
A related term, amorphous, means 'lacking definite form.'

meanings: Something necessary or indispensable.
An essential requirement or need for something.
examples: It is a necessity to review your homework before submitting it.
Jim packed all the necessities for the trip.
further_information: Originated from the Latin necessse meaning 'needful.'
Necessity implies 'being required or needed' while unavoidability implies 'something that will happen.'

meanings: To deny the existence, evidence, or truth of.
To nullify or cause to be ineffective.
examples: The current result of the experiment negates the earlier hypothesis.
The efforts of the team are negated by the lack of funds.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word negatio meaning 'denial.'
Negate means 'to deny the existence' while negative is 'the opposite of/not desirable.'

meanings: (Of words or language) Having little or no meaning.
(Of behavior, conduct, actions, etc.) Foolish, senseless, fatuous, or absurd.
examples: The nonsensical words of the baby are quite adorable.
He is difficult to understand because of his nonsensical attitude.
further_information: Originated from non + sense + ical meaning 'lack of' + 'perception' + adjectival suffix.
Nonsensical and senseless are interchangeable.

meanings: Widely and unfavorably known.
Publicly or generally known, typically for some bad quality or deed.
examples: Karl is notorious for being a latecomer.
Celebrities are notorious for their sensationalism.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word notus meaning 'known.'
Notorious connotes 'being known for something unfavorable.'

meanings: A person who is new to the circumstances, work, etc., in which he or she is placed.
examples: Novice workers are often trained by senior managers.
Every year, novice members of the clergy are introduced to the church.
further_information: Originated from the Late Latin word novus meaning 'new.'
In religions, a novice is 'a person who has been received into a religious order or congregation for a period of probation.'

meanings: To feed and protect. (v.)
Rearing, upbringing, training, education, or the like. (n.)
examples: Mothers typically have the natural instinct to nurture.
The nurture of young scientists is very important.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word nutrire meaning 'feed or cherish.'
In Biology, nurture means 'the environmental factors that partly determine the structure of an organism.'

meanings: A small fertile or green area in a desert region, usually having a spring or well.
Something serving as a refuge, relief, or pleasant change from what is usual, annoying, difficult, etc.
examples: It is difficult to find an oasis in the very hot desert.
The library is a valuable oasis in an otherwise busy city.
further_information: Virtually unchanged from its Late Latin form oasis meaning 'dwelling place.'
Oasis implies 'a place of refuge in a harsh environment.'

meanings: Very fat or overweight.
examples: The doctor warned him to avoid eating too much or else he will become obese.
That fat cat is too fluffy and obese to be healthy.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word edere meaning 'eat.'
Obese is relatively heavier than overweight.

meanings: Required as a matter of legal, moral or other rule.
examples: A lengthy speech is desirable but not obligatory.
You have to do the obligatory interview of the visiting alumni.
further_information: Originated from the Late Latin word obligatorium meaning 'binding.'
The synonym compulsory is generally used in contexts of education and business while obligatory refers to laws and rules.

meanings: To require or constrain, as by law, command, conscience, or force of necessity.
To place under a debt of gratitude for some benefit, favor, or service.
examples: Once signed, you are obliged to follow the contract.
I'm obliged to you for the help you have provided.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word ob + ligare meaning 'toward' + 'to bind.'
In Law, oblige is 'to bind by a verbal agreement or a contract.'
Obligatory is the adjectival form of oblige.

meanings: Unmindful or unconscious.
Without remembrance or memory.
examples: Sam becomes oblivious to his surroundings when reading books.
The campers were clearly oblivious to the danger.
further_information: Originated from the Old Latin word ob + levis meaning 'over' + 'smooth.'
Should not be confused with obvious which means 'easily seen or recognized.'
Usually followed by of or to.

meanings: Highly objectionable or offensive.
Annoying or objectionable due to being a show off or attracting undue attention to oneself.
examples: They did not like his obnoxious behavior.
Smith was quite obnoxious and loud during the party.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word ob + noxa meaning 'toward' + 'harm.'
Obnoxious evoke a stronger negative connotation than unpleasant or annoying.

meanings: Firmly or stubbornly adhering to one's purpose, opinion, etc.
Not easily controlled or overcome.
examples: He had an obstinate determination to pursue a career in films.
The obstinate problem of unemployment has dogged every government.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word ob + stinare meaning 'by' + 'to stand or be firm.'
Obstinate implies 'strong belief in one's ideas' while obdurate implies 'being unconvinced by others.'

meanings: Noticeable or prominent in an unwelcome way.
examples: The obtrusive child kept yelling during the movie.
Dad removed the obtrusive branch outside the window.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word ob + trudere + ive meaning 'in front of' + 'to thrust' + adjectival suffix.
Obtrusive is 'to be noticeable in an unwelcome way' while intrusive means 'to interfere in an annoying way.'

meanings: A person's usual or principal work or business, especially as a means of earning a living.
Possession, settlement, or use of land or property.
examples: People in a full time occupation tend to have structured lives.
The Roman occupation of Britain lasted for a long time.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word occupare meaning 'a taking possession, business or employment.'
Occupation implies 'an activity done with compensation; a job' while a profession implies 'a specialization that often requires training and schooling.'
Avocation is a related word meaning 'minor occupation or hobby.'

meanings: Deserving or causing hatred; Highly offensive.
examples: He had very few friends because of his odious and obnoxious attitude.
Taking the trash out is such an odious task that sometimes I don’t want to do.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word odium meaning 'hatred.'
Should not be confused with odorous meaning 'having a characteristic smell or odor.'

meanings: Best or most favorable.
examples: The optimal way to the grocery store is through 12th Street.
Engineers often think of optimal and efficient methods to do things.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word optimus + al meaning 'best' + suffix forming adjective.
Another form of optimal is optimum.

meanings: A public speaker, especially one of great eloquence.
examples: Cicero is known to be one of the greatest orators of ancient Greece.
Orators usually have natural charm and confidence that captivates the audience.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word orare meaning 'to speak or speak before a court or assembly.'
Orator implies 'a person who delivers a speech' whereas narrator is 'a person who gives an account or tells the story of events, experiences, etc.'

meanings: To compose or arrange (music) for performance by an orchestra.
To arrange or manipulate, especially by means of clever or thorough planning or maneuvering.
examples: Janis is tasked to orchestrate new pieces for the orchestra for the concert next year.
No one knew who orchestrated the attack which damaged the plaza.
further_information: Originated from the Greek word orkhestra referring to the semicircular space for a performance.
Orchestrate implies 'creating musical pieces for an orchestra' while compose is 'a general term for creating pieces of music.'

meanings: To swing or move to and fro.
To move back and forth between differing beliefs, opinions, conditions, etc.
examples: It is interesting to see the pendulum oscillate.
I oscillated between fear and fun during the comedic horror movie.
further_information: Originated from the French word osciller meaning 'to swing.'
Oscillate is the 'regular and continuous change from one form to another' while fluctuate means the 'irregular change in magnitude or direction.'

meanings: A portable or detachable lock with a pivoted or sliding shackle that can be passed through a link, ring, staple, or the like.
To fasten with or as with a padlock.
examples: He bought a stronger padlock for his house because of the break-ins around the area.
Please padlock the store after you leave, as you left it open last time.
further_information: Originated from the late 15th century word pad + lock meaning 'to fasten or secure.'
A padlock is 'something portable that is used to secure something' while a lock is 'a general term for a locking device typically built-in.'

meanings: Of, relating to, or resembling a palace.
Befitting or suitable for a palace.
examples: Sandra's house is quite palatial with 10 rooms and 6 bathrooms.
This figurine is so beautiful; it is palatial and elegant.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word palatium referring to the Palatine Hill.
Should not be confused with the word palatable meaning 'acceptable or agreeable to the taste.'

meanings: To make extremely, excessively, or completely dry, as heat, sun, and wind do.
To suffer from heat, thirst, or need of water.
examples: Failure of rains caused the land to become parched.
The runners crossed the finish line with parched throats, gasping for breath.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word persiccare meaning 'to dry thoroughly.'
Parched refers to smaller items or wanting water while arid refers to the weather or to a large area.

meanings: To ward off (a thrust, stroke, weapon, etc.).
An act or instance of parrying.
examples: They parried with difficult questions during the debate.
The knights' swords clashed in a parry.
further_information: Originated from the Italian word parare meaning 'ward off.'
Parry is 'to avoid' while block is 'to obstruct.'

meanings: An adherent or supporter of a person, group, party, or cause, especially a person who shows a biased, emotional allegiance.
Of, relating to, or characteristic of partisans; partial to a specific party, person, etc.
examples: The political party partisans claimed that the TV news was biased against them.
Newspapers have become increasingly partisan.
further_information: Originated from the Italian word parte meaning 'part.'
A partisan implies 'being a member of a certain group' while a follower is 'someone who follows a certain directive.'

meanings: Distinctive in nature or character from others.
An exclusive property or privilege belonging to a person.
examples: The peculiar painting combines many colors in one piece of work.
He is considered a peculiar because of his obsession with costumes.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word pecu meaning 'cattle.'
Peculiar implies 'unique or one-of-a-kind' while odd means 'different from the general public.'

meanings: A hanging ornament, such as an earring or the main piece suspended from a necklace.
That by which something is suspended, as the ringed stem of a watch.
examples: Her grandmother gave her a pendant as a birthday gift.
The diamond pendant costs quite a lot compared to the other pieces of jewelry.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word pendere meaning 'to hang.'
Should not be confused with the adjective pendent meaning 'hanging down.'

meanings: Dreamily or wistfully thoughtful.
examples: Kevin likes to spend time under the apple trees when he is in a pensive mood.
The pensive song impressed everyone in the concert with its thoughtful lyrics.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word pensare meaning 'weigh or consider.'
Should not be confused with the word pensieve which is a fictional object from the book series Harry Potter.

meanings: The act or faculty of perceiving, or apprehending by means of the senses or of the mind.
Immediate or intuitive recognition or appreciation, as of moral, psychological, or aesthetic qualities.
examples: Their perception of the current policies made them reject the idea.
He has a unique perception when it comes to painting and the visual arts.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word percipere meaning 'seize or understand.'
Should not be confused with perspective which means 'view point.'

meanings: Having or showing keenness of insight, understanding, or intuition.
examples: Amanda is quite a perceptive child, as she notices a lot of things around her.
Problems need perceptive answers to fully solve the root cause.
further_information: Originated from the Anglo-French word parceif + ive meaning 'to notice or see' + adjective forming suffix.
Should not be confused with receptive meaning 'having the quality of receiving or taking.'

meanings: Concerned with relatively minor, irrelevant, or superficial aspects of the subject in question.
Pertaining to, situated in, or constituting the edge.
examples: During meetings, we should avoid talking about peripheral issues too much.
The Jackson family lives in the peripheral part of the town.
further_information: Evolved from the Greek words peri which means 'around' and pherein which means 'to bear' and al which is a suffix with the general sense 'of the kind of.'
In Anatomy, peripheral means 'near the surface or outside of.'
Other words having the same prefix peri are perimeter, periscope, perigee etc.

meanings: To pass into or through every part of.
examples: The smell of freshly baked cookies permeated the entire house.
Acids usually permeate most metallic surfaces.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word per + meare meaning 'through' + 'pass or go.'
Permeate is 'to pass through' while penetrate implies 'to break through.'

meanings: To cause to continue or prevail indefinitely.
examples: Naming the library after its founder perpetuates his memory.
It might be best to back off and not perpetuate the argument.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word perpetuus meaning 'continuing throughout.'
Should not be confused with perpetrate meaning 'to commit/to carry out.'

meanings: (Especially of an unwelcome influence or physical effect) Spreading widely throughout an area or a group of people.
examples: The epidemic is alarming the authorities as it becomes pervasive.
Ageism is pervasive and entrenched in our society.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word pervadere + ive meaning 'to spread' + adjective forming suffix.
Should not be confused with persuasive meaning 'having the power or ability to persuade.'

meanings: Of little or no importance or consequence.
Of lesser or secondary importance, merit, etc.
examples: Petty arguments are often a waste of time and effort.
No one likes a petty person who creates unnecessary tension in the group.
further_information: Originated from the French word petit meaning 'small.'
Should not be confused with pretty meaning 'pleasing or attractive to the eye.'

meanings: Selfless concern for human welfare and advancement.
The activity of donating to such persons or purposes in this way.
examples: Many hospitals were built as a result of private philanthropy.
We are teaching our child the value of philanthropy, as it promotes kindness and empathy.
further_information: Originated from the Greek word phil + anthropos meaning 'loving' + 'mankind.'
Philanthropy implies 'long term, strategic giving, focused on re-building' while charity refers to 'short term immediate response, focused on rescue and relief.'

meanings: The highest or culminating point, as of success, power, fame, etc.
To place on or as on a pinnacle.
examples: Receiving the award is the pinnacle of his career because of his dedication and efforts.
The brothers have reached the pinnacle of sport.
further_information: Originated from the Late Latin word pinna meaning 'wing or point.'
Pinnacle evokes a stronger emotion than peak.

meanings: Having or showing a dutiful spirit of reverence for God or an earnest wish to fulfill religious obligations.
(Of a hope) Sincere but unlikely to be fulfilled.
examples: Saints are pious and devoted to their beliefs even to the point of sacrificing their lives.
The pious literature contains historical accounts of the religion.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word pius + ous meaning 'dutiful' + adjective suffix.
Pious implies 'devotion to a belief or religion.'

meanings: To arouse an emotion or provoke to action.
A feeling of irritation or resentment, as from a wound to pride or self-esteem.
examples: His interest was piqued when he saw the discount.
Johnson was in a pique when he was not invited to the party.
further_information: Originated from the French word piquer meaning 'to prick or sting.'
Also pronounced piqué [pi-KEY] meaning 'a fabric of cotton, spun rayon, or silk, woven lengthwise with raised cords.'

meanings: Of, relating to, or serving as a pivot.
Of vital or critical importance.
examples: The pivotal character the movie was not very convincing.
Being promoted was a pivotal moment of his career in software development.
further_information: Originated from the French word pue which means 'tooth of a comb' and the Spanish word puya which means 'point.'
Pivotal implies 'a moment which caused significant change.'

meanings: To appease or pacify, especially by concessions or conciliatory gestures.
examples: The CEO tried to placate the angry directors during the board meeting.
The mother used a stuffed toy to placate the crying baby.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word placere meaning 'to please.'
Should not be confused with placard which means 'a paperboard sign or notice, as one posted in a public place or carried by a demonstrator or picketer.'

meanings: Of, relating to, or characteristic of the Greek philosopher Plato or his doctrines.
Free from sensual desire, especially in a relationship between two persons of the opposite sex.
examples: A lot of his students challenged the Platonic philosophy.
Friends typically have platonic relationships that are built over time.
further_information: Originated from the Greek word Platonikos referring to the followers of Plato.
Should not be confused with plutonic which refers to a class of igneous rocks.

meanings: Easily bent or flexible.
Easily influenced or persuaded.
examples: Leather is usually dried under the sun to make it pliable.
Teachers shape the pliable minds of children to help them grow into effective adults.
further_information: Originated from the French word plier + ply meaning 'to bend' + adjectival suffix.
Pliable implies 'ability to change shape' while malleable means 'capable of being extended.'

meanings: Small pincers with long jaws, for bending wire, holding small objects, etc.
examples: Pliers are used to grip and tighten objects, especially nuts and bolts.
Can you buy the high-end pliers at the store?
further_information: Originated from the Latin word plicare meaning 'to fold.'
Pliers can also be spelled as plyers (British).

meanings: A digital audio or video file or recording, usually part of a themed series, that can be downloaded from a website to a media player or computer.
To record and upload as a podcast.
examples: I love listening to podcasts about music and artists.
We are scheduled to podcast tomorrow night during primetime.
further_information: Combination of 21st century words iPod + broadcast.
Podcast typically refers to recorded discussions about topics.

meanings: Full of residents or inhabitants, such as a region.
Jammed or crowded with people.
examples: The populous city is becoming industrialised because new companies are flocking to it.
Shanghai is one of the most populous cities in the world.
further_information: Originated from the Late Latin word populus meaning 'people.'
Populous refers to the number of people in an area while populace refers to the inhabitants of a place.

meanings: To read or study with steady attention or application.
A small opening or orifice, as in the skin or a leaf, for perspiration, absorption, etc.
examples: The students pored over the old statue at the museum.
Sweat poured from every pore in the runner's body.
further_information: Originated from the Greek word poros meaning 'pore or passage.'

meanings: To put off to a later time.
To place after in order of importance or estimation.
examples: Smith had to postpone the meeting because they're all busy.
He had to postpone his dream of becoming an artist.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word post + ponere meaning 'after' + 'to place.'
Postpone is 'to do something at a later time' while defer means 'to decide something later on.'

meanings: The state or condition of having little or no money, goods, or means of support.
Deficiency of necessary or desirable ingredients, qualities, etc.
examples: There is rampant poverty in some parts of the city.
The poverty of the soil makes it unfit for crops.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word pauper meaning 'poor.'
Poverty implies 'lack of necessities' while destitution implies 'a state of having absolutely none of the necessities.'

meanings: An introductory statement.
The introductory part of a statute, deed, or the like, stating the reasons and intent of what follows.
examples: He opened the program with a quick preamble about the history of the town.
A preamble was written by the author for his new book.
further_information: Originated from the Late Latin word praemabulus meaning 'going before.'
A preamble also refers to the introductory statement in a constitution.

meanings: An unpleasantly difficult, perplexing, or dangerous situation.
examples: Jane needs all the help she can get to overcome her predicament.
Careless decisions can get you in a predicament.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word prae + dicare meaning 'forth or before' + 'proclaim.'
Predicament refers to 'generally negative situation' while dilemma refers to 'puzzling situation.'

meanings: Preceding and leading up to the main part, matter, or business.
examples: Preliminary discussion is conducted to prepare for the workshop.
He needs to take the preliminary exam before the finals.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word prae + limen meaning 'before' + 'threshold.'
Preliminary means 'something that comes before the main subject' while preparatory is 'preparing for the main idea.'

meanings: To pay or arrange to pay beforehand or before due.
examples: Banks usually allow you to prepay your loan.
Prepaying allows for better management of one's finances.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word pre + pay meaning 'before' + 'to settle a debt.'
Prepay is 'paying before due' while postpaid is 'to pay after usage.'

meanings: Characterized by assumption of dignity or importance, especially when exaggerated or undeserved.
examples: A pretentious person is not liked by anyone.
They avoided the pretentious businessman and chose someone who was genuine.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word prae + tendere meaning 'before' + 'to claim.'
Should not be confused with precocious meaning 'unusually advanced or mature in development, especially mental development.'

meanings: Well-advanced or competent in any art, science, or subject.
examples: Janice is proficient in both Maths and Chemistry.
He was proficient at his job and was soon promoted.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word pro + facere meaning 'on behalf of' + 'do or make.'
An expert is better than someone who is merely proficient.

meanings: Utterly and shamelessly immoral or dissipated; Recklessly wasteful or extravagant.
examples: The profligate president spent the company’s money on personal expenses.
The heiress is a profligate who wants the most expensive things.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word pro + fligere meaning 'forward' + 'strike down.'
Profligate (n.) is someone who 'engages in immoral and wasteful acts' while prodigal (n.) implies 'someone who was immoral but is now reformed, as in the prodigal son who eventually comes back home.'

meanings: The act of offering or suggesting something for acceptance, adoption, or performance.
examples: The proposal for the science project is quite impressive.
Proposals should always be clear and convincing.
further_information: Originated from the Old French word pro + poser + al meaning 'forth' + 'put or place' + adjectival suffix.
A proposal also means 'an offer of marriage.'

meanings: Of or in the future.
Potential, likely, or expected.
examples: He is so excited to send applications to prospective colleges.
Jane is meeting with her prospective clients.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word pro + specere meaning 'forward' + 'look at.'
Prospective implies 'more likely to happen' whereas potential implies 'may or may not happen.'

meanings: To be successful or fortunate, especially in financial aspects.
examples: To prosper in one's career is everybody's dream.
Samantha prospered as an artist though her major in university was Economics.
further_information: Originated from the Old Latin word pro + spes meaning 'for' + 'hope.'
Prosper implies 'to succeed in material or financial aspect' while succeed implies 'to accomplish what is attempted.'

meanings: Having or characterized by financial success or good fortune.
Well-to-do or well-off.
examples: It is difficult to maintain a prosperous business during an economic meltdown.
Janna is happy to have a prosperous family that supports her.
further_information: Originated from the Old Latin pro + spes + ous meaning 'for' + 'hope' + adjectival suffix for nouns.
Prosper means 'the condition of having a good fortune' while affluence means 'abundance of financial wealth.'

meanings: To reduce to dust or powder, as by pounding or grinding.
To demolish or crush completely.
examples: Make sure to pulverize the dried herbs to bring out the flavors.
Prepare to pulverize the competition tomorrow during the marathon.
further_information: Originated from the Late Latin word pulvis meaning 'dust.'
Pulverize is spelled pulverize in British English.

meanings: Sharply affecting the organs of taste or smell, as if by a penetrating power.
Caustic, biting, or sharply expressive.
examples: We need to find the source of that pungent smell and get rid of it.
Team leaders should avoid pungent remarks when criticizing.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word pungere meaning 'to prick, pierce, or sting.'
Pungent generally refers to smell or taste while potent refers to 'having strength.'

meanings: Having an old-fashioned attractiveness or charm.
Strange, peculiar, or unusual in an interesting, pleasing, or amusing way.
examples: My family bought the quaint old house in the village.
She has a quaint sense of humor which some people don’t understand.
